titleStmt.author: Ravenscroft, Edward, 1654?-1707.
Molière, 1622-1673. Bourgeois gentihomme.
Molière, 1622-1673. Monsieur de Pourceaugnac.

notesStmt.note: Published later, 1675 with title: Mamamouchi, or, The citizen turn'd gentleman.
Taken from Molière's "Le bourgeois gentihomme" and "Monsieur de Pourceaugnac".
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

div.p: THE CITIZEN TURN'D Gentleman: A COMEDY.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Dring, at the White-Lyon next Chancery-Lane end in Fleetstreet, 1672.

list.head: Men.
list.item: MR. Iorden Formerly a Citizen, but now sets up for a Gentleman. Mr. Nokes.
Young Iorden His son, in love with Marina. Mr. Cademan.
Mr. Cleverwit In love with Lucia. Mr. Crosby.
Sir Simon Softhead A Country Knight. Mr. Underhil.
Trickmore Cureal Two men of Intrigue. Mr. Harris. Mr. Sandford.

list.head: Vallet de Chambre.
list.item: Maistre Iaques French Master to the Citizen. Mr. Angel.

list.head: Women.
list.item: LUcia Daughter to Mr. Iorden. Mrs. Bittertun.
Marina A young Lady. Mrs. Burroughs.
Betty Trickmore Trickmores Sister, her woman. Mrs. Leigh.

div.head: TO HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS Prince Rupert.
div.p: MY ambition of dedicating this to your Royal Highness, proceeds not from the more than ordinary encouragement it receiv'd from you, when it appear'd on the Stage: tho' of thirty times it has been acted, you seldom fail'd to honour it with your presence. 'Twould be presumption in me to examine why you did it that Grace; and vain-glory to attribute it to the merits of the Play, since the best have not receiv'd the like honour.

Nor does the envie of Criticks force me to invoke your Princely Patronage; it were as vain to think the name of a Patron should shield it from their censures, as it would hinder the rude rable (if engrav'd on the front of a house) from breaking the windows. The malice of these, and the rudeness of the others may lead 'em to do either, without convincing them they are guilty of any disrespect. And Criticks stand up as zealously for the liberty of their Tongues, as Fanaticks for liberty of Conscience; and rail as spitefully against Plays, as that perverse Generation does against Magistrates and Governours.

The third common pretence of Authors I likewise disown: I boast not of any particular favours receiv'd; blessings flow from Princes, as light does from the Sun, which shines on all at once. They oblige not Persons, but Nations: Of that great Vertue, SIR, you stand a glorious Example. You engag'd your self in our intestine dissentions: You was the thunderbolt of War; the enemies where-ever you came, or fled or fell before you: You threw your self into the storm to
save us; and when it had shipwrack'd the best of Monarchs, your Piety led you to exile with the Son: when his Country and Subjects forsook him, you did not; but with him shar'd the dangers and hardships of banishment, till Heaven (which laid the yoke of tyranny for punishment on our rebellious necks) was pleas'd to restore him to us, or rather us to our King. The Sun had it been so long absent, could not be more welcome; with him like a train of glorious Lights, return'd the Royal Family, and not long after your Royal Self; after you you drew a chain of Blessings, Freedom, Peace, Religion, Unity, which ever since we have enjoyed: What foes we have abroad, we need not fear, whilst we have your Counsel for Conduct, and your Sword for Execution. You still like Englands Angel Guardian stand ready to defend it; and so long as we have either Memory or Gratitude, every tongue must speak your fame, and every heart dedicate it self to you as a Trophee, owing to your gallantry. What a noble stock of Virtue must you have so entirely to captivate the hearts of a Nation, to which you was born a stranger! Who, when they hear your name, or see it here prefixt, will not repeat it, and say, You are the Heroe of the world; then in a transport run o'er your mighty Deeds and Actions, which make you famous above mankind in our present Annals, and will with excess of Glory bear your name to after Ages? How just an occasion have I here, to say all that can be said of man without danger of being thought a flatterer? But, Sir, were you less than what you are, I could say more: Now all is truth, nor can that truth be contain'd in an Epistle. And I know the perfect Heroe blushes as much at the narration of his Virtues, as the Lady exactly Beautiful at the relation of her Perfections: Praise seems to lessen both, for 'tis thought we rather speak what they should be, than what they are. Virtue ought to find Imitators, and Beauty more admirers than commenders: Nor would I give the most malicious any ground to think you can be flatter'd; or that I hope by flattery and insinuation to make attonement for this presumption: Your Virtues drew it on you; those Virtues
which have so much oblig'd our Nation, engage all hearts to pay our thanks as tribute to you: Involv'd in the common fate, I take this occasion to attest my acknowledgements, and to beg your Royal Highness to look upon this, not so much the Dedication of a Play, as of a Heart. That other Poets stand at an awful distance, argues not my rudeness, but the greatness of my zeal which prompts me to believe that the boldness of performing so great a Duty, is not a crime equal to the forbearance; And I shall account it my glory to have led the way, where others made a stand.

closer.signed: Your Royal Highness's Most humble and Most obedient Servant, Edward Ravenscroft.

lg.l: GAllants you're so unconstant grown of late,
That Plays and Mistrisses have the same fate;
For both with you grow quickly out of date.
Each with variety so taken is,
You'l see but once or the same Play or Miss.
Go on, we'l not your liberty retrench,
Like this for change▪ as you wou'd do a wench:
But know, when the translating vein is past,
That you must not expect new Plays so fast.
Then Wit and sence will come into request,
And something more than a vain Fopp well dress'd.
The Taylor now in Plays makes the best jest.
And 'twill be time to check this full carreer
Of Plays, and Act but two or three a year.
With plenty you are cloy'd, but when grown scarce
You will esteem 'em more; and then a Farce
Will entertain you for a Month at least;
Not what is good, but scarce does make a feast.
Then shall the Knight that had a knock in's Cradle,
Such as Sir Martin, or Sir Arthur Addle,
Be flock'd unto, as the great Heroes now
In Playes of Rhyme and Noyse with wond'rous show.
Then shall the House (to see these Hectors kill and slay,
That bravely fight out the whole plot of th' Play,)
Be for at least six months full ev'ry day.
If beauty grows so scarce, your Misses too
Will find that you'l to them more constant grow.
Now the enjoy'd you slight; if you're inclin'd
To visit them, it is not to be kind.
You play the criticks, you find fault and jeer,
And 'gainst your Miss are wittily severe;
As fain you'd be on Plays when you come here.
You like prejudicated Iudges sit;
There Beauties faults you find, here those of Wit..
'Gainst both I've heard Women and Poets say,
No Critick is like him that ev'ry day
Sees a fresh Girl, and each Week a new Play.
FRom the Court party we hope no success,
Our Author is not one of the Nobless,
That bravely does maintain his Miss in Town,
Whilst my great Lady is with speed sent down,
And forc'd in Country Mansion house to fix,
That Miss may rattle here in Coach and six.
If one of these the Author was, perchance
You'd joyn your int'rest, and the Play advance:
For tho' you great ones and you Courtiers be
Not o'er good natur'd, you've civilitie.
Nor is he one you call a Town-Gallant,
Who for fine cloathes does seldom money want:
But drives at cheaper rates the sinful trade,
Seduces Wives, sometimes a Chamber-maid:
That at Jero's or Satt'lins goes to dinner;
And thence repairs to th' Play to meet a sinner:
And here with Burgundy and brisk sableé
Inspir'd, with vizard-Masque holds reparteé.
After the Play in joulting Hack he goes,
Where his companions have their Rendevouz.
In pairs they meet; and Ala mode of France
They sup, they have the fiddles too and dance:
Tow'rds morning, when they think of going home,
Each Gallant on a Couch in the next room,
In's turn, takes gentle solace with his Punk;
Drops her a Guinney, and sends her home half drunk.
All of that Gang by this confession too
Are lost. Ladies, our Author trusts in you.
He is a man as modest for his age,
As most you've seen, who know him dare engage
That he has kept 'till now his pusillage.
But alas! the world to that pass is grown,
The modish women are asham'd to own
A sober man: to like his Play will be,
As great a scandal as his companie.
For he observes, and it is very true,
That modesty's not much approv'd in you.
And is of late so out of fashion grown,
She that is honest scarcely dares it own.
But does, howe'er her mind affected is,
Put on the brisk gay carriage of a Miss.
But Ladies, hope the Poet one day may
Converted be; for he that writes a Play,
If not debauch'd, yet is in a fair way.
To gain your favours he resolves to be
In all the Town the greatest debaucheé:
And in a very little time may grow
Debauch'd enough to be asham'd of you.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAge 3. line 10. for does, read you. p. 11. l. 26. f. Ah I Lucia, r. Ah Lucia. p. 17. l. 3. f. purrey, r. parry. p. 17. l. 10. f. capritius's r. capricioes. p. 18. l. 16. f. wants which whet, r. want which whets. p. 33. l. 4. f. on, r. in. p. 33. l. 29. f. exclude, r. seclude. p. 34. l. 14. f. How, Sir? a, r. How, Sir? Jord. A. p. 39. l. 9. f. so many, r. so much. p. 47. l. 9. f. what, r. why. p. 48. l. 1. f. clear, r. chear. p. 56. l. 22. f. you interest, r. your interest, p. 72. l. 27. f. swoon'd, r. swoonded. In the Prologue at the Middle-temple, l. 14. in some f. do moere, r. do no more.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: The Curtain draws up and discovers the Musick Master siting at a Table surrounded by Musicians Composing, the Dancing Master and Dancers practising steps on each side of the Stage.
Enter Mr Jorden in a Morning-Gown, Jaques, Foot-boy.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: SO, so, Gentlemen, I see you are at it, come let's have a sight of your little Droll.

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: How, Sir, our Droll?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Eh, your what do you call't, your Prologue of Song and Dance.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Our Dialogue you mean, well 'tis ready.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have made you stay a little too long, but as I am a Gentleman, and as I hope to be a Knight, (mark that, for so I mean to be once in my life) my Taylor was in fault.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: We wait your leisure with a great deal of willingness.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He brought home this Indian Gown, Cap and Slippers,— how do you like 'em?

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Extreamly well.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: You appear very graceful.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: So, so, Iack— Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here, Sir; what would you please to have?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Nothing, I called to see if you be diligent in your attendance: how do you like my livery?

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Very fine and noble.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Jack?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Who do he speak to?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Begar den let him call me be me name, me be no shauck.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Iack, come hither Iack.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Shauck, me be no shauck, call your Englishman shauck, me be called Maitre Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Master Iack come hither.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ho, ho, dat be ver well, here be your tres humble, and tres obeisant vallet.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hold back my Gown, and you Sarrah hold back the other side,— so, see Gentlemen, here is a little loose morning garb, does it please you?

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: Neat and Gentile.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Stay, pull it off, that they may view me round— How do you like me from top to toe?

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Your habit is worthy admiration.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: Gallant from head to foot.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: My Suit will come home by and by, that will be fine indeed.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: The ceremony requires it.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, you mean my Daughter's wedding, but know there is more in the wind than so: this day I am to begin to court a Mistress, a Knights Daughter, I'l assure you.

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: And all our preparations are for her entertainment.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p:
And to render my self more acceptable, I have required your helps to make me an accomplisht Gentleman; if
singing and dancing won't win her, the Devil's in her.— Well, I'l see your Dance rehearsed; but first let me hear the Song.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: I sigh all the night, and I languish all day,
And much to be pitty'd I am:
E'er since your bright eyes, my heart did surprise
I could not extinguish the flame:
But you, since y'ave known my heart was your own,
Tho' before you was kind, now scornful are grown:
If so cruel you prove
To the man that does love;
Ah Phyllis! Ah! Phyllis, what fate
Have you in reserve for the wretch that you hate?

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast. Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But me thinks this Song is a little too doleful, and enough to put a woman into the dumps, if she have any kindness for me.

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: 'Tis a delicate Air, and the words are not amiss.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I learnt a very pretty one t'other day of a friend; stay, how begins it?

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Nay, I know not:

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: There is something of Mutton in it.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: Mutton?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes,— oh, no, no, no, 'twas Lamb— ah— I have it.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: My Mistress is as kind as fair,
My Mistress is as kind as fair,
And as gentle as Lambs are;
And yet alass, alass, ah lass,
Sometimes to me
She'l as cruel be,
As in the woodfierce Wolves and Tygers are.

sp.p: Is it not very sprightly?

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: As can be.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: And you humour it well.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, now for my dancing, and because the Morning is far spent, I will only practise over the Minuets: Ah, of all Dances that pleases me most.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: Come, Sir, begin; your hat, Sir, so now your honour: La, la, fa, la, la, fa, la, la, (bis) Dances aukerdly. not too fast, la, la, la, la, keep you leg▪ straight, la, la, la, don't hunch up your shoulders so; la, la, fa, la, la, la, la, you carry your arms as if they were broken, la, la, la, la, la, hold up your head, keep your toes out, la, la, la, don't loll out your tongue, la, la, la, and make such faces, la, la, la, la, as if you were on the close-stool, la, la, la, &c. so, so.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Euh!

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: very well.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: I hope to get credit by him.

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: Money you mean: Well Mr. Iordan, it is not enough to proceed thus alone, but you would do well once a week to have a Musick Club at your house, and play and sing in consort, it will much benefit you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And so I will, now you put me in mind on't.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: And once a fortnight a Ball, you will have the whole Court with you, and all the fine Ladies of the Town.

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: 'Twill make you known at Court.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: And familiar with Noblemen: a Gentleman is known by what company he keeps.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You advise well, sweet-hearts; but are you perfect at your Dialogue and Dance?

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: We intend you shall see it perform'd.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, 'tis too late now: look they be perfect against dinner, and I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p: I'l warrant the Dancers.

sp.speaker: Mus. Mast.
sp.p: And I'l ingage for the Musick.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, your servant; stay, shew me with what reverence I ought to accost my Mistress, 'twill be the next thing I shall have need off.

sp.speaker: Danc. Mast.
sp.p:
To do it with respect, you must first draw
your leg behind you and bow, then march up towards her with three Congees forward, and at the last you bow so low as to kiss her hand; try it once over:— Very well; your servant.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your servant.— Come now to my french lesson.

sp.speaker: Mr. Iaq.
sp.p: Vell, Sir, have you got te Catalogue of te French words me give you in your memoire.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, and I find I can bring 'em all in, in discourse with my Mistress; tho I can't talk French to her, 'twill be next to't, she'll think I can.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: 'Tis be me invention, and judge Maitre Iorden, if it be no ver rational, bevore me teash you te rules, you be inure to our langage, by making it as it vere your own.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Nay, I think to make it our own is a very ready way to learn it.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And 'tis course vill ver much refine te English Landguage: If you observe all travellers give te ver many littil graces to their discourse vith te tange of te French, you shall no hear speak, one sentence vithout Bon mein, jaunté devoir, efsort, &c.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have observ'd it. But to our Lesson, I am in haste.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Now proceed we to teash you te right pronunciation of te Vowels, because of Letters tey be te sheif, and no word is or can be vithout one or more of tem.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Vowels, why are there any vowels in our Alphabet?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, te number be fife, and te same vith yours, these be they, A, E, I, O, U. A be pronounce like a, u, au; As for Example in some English vords, all, fall, and no as in ale, stale.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A, au.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Right, A opening strongly your moush, and drawing your jaws vide asunder.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Au, right.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: E, is pronunce by heaving te neather jaw to te upper, A, E.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: E, A, E, E, directly.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I be pronounce not as your English man do Latin, Qui mihi, but more like to te second vowel E; and is form by drawing your jaws yet more near den bevore, and drawing the two corners of your moush to te ears, A, E, I.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A, E, I, I, I; Dad, 'tis true, may Learning flourish.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O is form by opening te jaws, closing te lips at the two corner, and opening tem in te middile, O.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Let me see that again.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O, O,

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Right, O, O, O, nothing more true, A, E, I, O, O, I, O; ah, 'tis admirable.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Te opening of te moush is a little round representing one O.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What a fine thing is knowledge!

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: U be form by approashing te teet vithout quite joyning them; trusting your lips at full length from your face, approashing also one te oder vithout closing, and tis vowel requires te strongest and te freest expiration of your breat of any Letter vhatsoere.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: U, U.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Not as you pronounce it, like You, more like Eu, u, vith a long breating out of our breat.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Like Eu, u.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Right, u, as if you made a moush to mock somebody. To morrow, Sir, we'l proceed to te Dipthongs which be eleven, and te next day ve'l mannage te consonants.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Consonants?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Tey are te oter Letters.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I shall make a shift to learn 'em all at once, I am pretty apt because I bend my mind to't.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Noting is hard to a villing mind.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But how many did you say the five vowels were?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You nam'd te number, fife, Sir, fife.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Right, the five vowels are five, I'l note that down in my Table-book: numbers are the worst things can be trusted to my memory. A Lady at Court yesterday morning asked me how many the ten Commandements were, and I protest I had forgot: I have noted this next to that.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Tings ve no oft tink off soon run out of te brain.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, what is a good expression to break ones mind to a Lady, and to let her know I love her?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Be you in love den Maitre?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Vith whom?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Truly I have never yet seen her, but I shall anon.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Vell, Sir, vou'd you have te expression in Prose or in te Verse?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Not in Verse.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: In prose den?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, nor in Prose: I would have it neither in Prose nor Verse.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Jerne, it must be in one or te oder.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Why so, if I won't have it so?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Because, Sir, all expression be in te one or te oter.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What have we nothing but Prose and Verse? what a mad language is ours? I'l learn French so much the sooner for't.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Dat be te same in all languages, dat vich is no Prose is Verse, and dat vich is no Verse is Prose.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What is it we talk now?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Prose.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, if I say to my Mistress, Fair Lady, the lustre of your fair eyes doe wound my heart.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Dat be te Prose: you may add, and their bright flame has burnt it to a Cinder.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, I'l study a speech, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Tayler, Sir, has sent your suit home again.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ah, the shoulder-knot stands right now: go fetch my Sword and Belt, my Hat and Periwig, that I may dress me presently.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, Here's a servant sent to you from the next house, to inform you that there are some persons sick, and to desire they may not be disturbed with your Musick.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The Musick has been gone a good while.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Neighbours say 'tis fitter for you to exercise your Musick, Dancing and Fencing in the Schools.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A company of fools, they'll teach a Gentleman what to do, will they?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your gentility is troublesome to the whole Neighbourhood: they have often complain'd of the disturbance you make with Musick, Dancing and Fencing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p:
Pish, a man shan't learn good breeding for them I
warrant you, 'tis a sign they want it, they are so rude to talk so: What's a Gentleman but his liberty?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Every body much wonders what you mean by learning to dance at these years.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It's a greater wonder they are not so wise as to know, 'tis never too late to learn.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And to speak French.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It is altogether spoke at Court.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Court, Sir, is no fit place for you, nor you no fit man for it.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I not fit for the Court! I was born a Courtier, only I was spoil'd in the bringing up.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Grand-father, Sir, brought you up in his own way.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your Grand-father! alas poor old silly Citt, I cannot but laugh to think what an Aufe he was to imagine that I would stand sneaking in my Shop all my life with my Cap in my hand, crying, What do you lack, Gentlemen, choice of good Silkes: I'd have you to know Lucia, I have no such Mechanick Spirit in me. Now he is dead, I defie Pater-Noster-Row, and all within my Lord Mayor's jurisdiction.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Grand-father, Sir, was held a wise man.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A wise man, and an Alderman, ha, ha, ha. A rich man you mean.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Sir, I mean a wise man.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Alas, Luce, you are a fool, you know not what you say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Very well! ha, ha, ha, why, what is it you say?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That the Court—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I speak not now of the Court, I ask, if you know, what it is you say?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And I tell you, Sir, I say that the Court—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pish, the Girl's a fool; I say again I talk not now of the Court, but ask you if you know what this is you speak to me and I to you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What is it? 'tis English.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: True, but what else?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nothing else, 'tis every word English.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Was there ever such a dunce? what are these words?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What are these words?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes: What?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Letters make Syllables, syllables words, words sentences, and sentences a discourse.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And is this all you know?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: God help your head, what a fine fellow shou'd I be, were I as ignorant as your self.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Where lies my ignorance? what was it I said, say you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: 'Twas Prose you fool.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Prose!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes Prose, all that is prose is not verse, and all that is not verse is not prose: La you there now: Do you know what it is you do, when you say U?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I say U.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pish— but what do you do then? Come, say U.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well Sir, U.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well; what did you do then?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I did as you bid me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Invincible stupidity, you open'd your mouth, thrust your lips out at length forward, let your under jaw fall almost to meet the upper, and strongly sent out your breath— U— see there— U— as it were make a mouth at one— U— I cou'd puzle you too, with asking you how many the five vowels are, and tell you as much of every one of them— this 'tis to be a Vertoso.— Hah— this fencing-master comes not yet— Boy, run toth' door, and when you see him coming, bring me word.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: These exercises of fencing and dancing in my opinion were fitter for my brother, he is not above twenty years old.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p:
Your Brother— puh— he can ne'r be a Gentleman. I was born a Citizen my self, and his Mother was a Citizen born, he was not allyed to gentility on either side, forty or fifty pounds a year will maintain him in his native quality— but for you daughter, because you are a gentlewoman by your Mothers side, I have provided better; you shall be married to the Suffolk Knight that will be here anon; the Articles of Marriage are agreed upon by your Uncle who is his townsman. The writings are already drawn and sent up with the settlement of your Joynture, and provision for younger Children;
if he comes time enough you shall be married to day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To day?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, to day, for I long to have a Gentleman, and a Knight for my Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have no ambition to be a Lady.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Marry him your self then.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: If you anger me, I'l make you a Dutchess, a Countess at least.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Truly I have no mind.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Truly I have a mind.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I would not marry yet.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yet you shall marry.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Not Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He is a fool, Father.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Therefore you are a worse fool if you refuse him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If I marry I'l have none but Master Cleverwit.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But Master Cleverwit will have none of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Will you stand to that? shall I have him if he'l have me?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, if you'l marry Sir Simon, if he refuses you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh! here he comes to our purpose. Master Cleverwit, do you love my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I did once Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Wou'd you have her still?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You discharged me, and I would not do her that wrong, (since you have provided a Knight, and a richer man for her Husband) to be her hindrance.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: La you there; I told you so.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: False man!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Besides, Sir, you know I told you I have engag'd my self elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh heavens! am I then forsaken?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir Simon will down with you anon as much a fool as he is.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Besides, I have so entire a friendship for you, that did I love her still as once I did, I wou'd refuse her tho' you wou'd double her portion, and say take her, if you did not judge it convenient.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I know you are a worthy person, and my good friend; and truly Sir, had you not told me your Father was not a Gentleman, but a Citizen, you should have had her before any man.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Now Master Cleverwit pray be you Judge; ought not my Daughter to marry Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Without doubt: he is a Knight?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: He is a fool too?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A little shallow my Brother writes me word, but that is a blot in many a Knights Escutcheon.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: So much the better for her.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye Sir, as how?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: She that wedds a Fool, marries her self to his Estate— she'l have all, do all, dispose of all, and rule the rost as long as she lives.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, there is one without would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I will be with you again presently; in the mean time pray take some pains with the baggage; you have powerful reasons, and can perswade.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I'l labour to serve you— but my self first—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Perfidious man! is it thus you use a Maid that loved you? was it not crime enough to be unconstant to deprive me of your self, but to condemn me with your own mouth to marry one I ne'r can love?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Ah I, Lucia!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nothing but this proof of your hatred can dispossess my heart of Love. But I will dye rather than let it return tho' you'd be constant.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Now is the time to tell you—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, to make the wound mortal, I will hear no cause of your infidelity, nor can you have a just pretence: farewel, farewel.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Lucia stay.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why do you hold me?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Hear me, speak, or if you needs will go, go undeceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Speak then what you would say in as few words as you can.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: My inconstancy, dearest Lucia, was but feigned, and a disguise to carry on a plot laid to divert your expected Lover, and preserve you mine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You maintain'd your Rivals cause, and sooth'd my father in his injustice.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I have, ere since I heard the news of your new Lover, prepar'd him for this revolt: long since I declar'd to him I was engag'd to another, and showed this compliance, that he might not suspect fire hid under the ashes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If this be true, make use of these few minutes to inform me what inventions you have fram'd to divert this unlucky marriage?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Be not inquisitive to know what tricks we mean to play; you shall as in Comedies have the divertisement of the surprise; let it suffice to tell you, Trickmore is the main engine. I sent him last night to stay at the Inn where the Coach lies, to take a strict view of him and his Retinue, and to make as great a discovery of our Knight Errant as he can, that we may the better know how to manage him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Father returns.—

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: A Daughters reputation is safe no longer than her obedience continues, and a Daughter ought not to regard whether her Husband be handsome or wise, when a Parent commands: Riches, and Gentility are above Youth and Beauty▪ they fade in the marriage-bed, the other accompany you to the grave, and descend to posterity.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you are a good man, you speak admirable things.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Sir, I have almost prevailed, and she will be brought with a little more counsel to obey you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How happy is our Family in such a friend, how pleas'd I am you give me hopes I shall see my Daughter a Lady to night and that I shall have a Knight for my Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: But can it be to night?

div.stage: Enter a Boy and T. Trickmore in disguise.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Simon arrived late last night, and sent me word just now, that he will be here within this hour, or a little more, but I'l immediately take Coach and go to him, for I am impatient to see my Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Sir Simon arrived, and no news from Trickmore yet?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, here is one come from your Fencing-master to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, are you Master Iorden?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I am Master Iorden.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your Fencing-master is sick, very sick, and cannot come to day, but has sent me in's place to give you Lesson.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, now I don't know whether 'tis best to go or stay.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Oh stay Sir by all means, now the man is come.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, if you please to stay, you shall learn more in one half quarter of an hour, than e're you yet learnt in your whole life.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: There's encouragement.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I'l show you a trick to undo all you fence with.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Say you so, come then— Boy take my gown.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Sir, we'l take a walk in the Garden; with a little more pains, I shall perfect her obedience.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your servant Sir,— Lucie, you'l remember to go to Mistris Manira at the time appointed, and wait on her hither.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And when you go, present her with this ring as a token of my love.

div.stage: Trickmore throws off his Cloak and appears accouter'd like a Fencing-Master, with Foiles under his Arm.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
Come Sir, your reverence— Your body straight, let your body lay a little more stress on your left thigh, your legs not so stradling, your feet in a direct line, your wrist joint opposite to your hip, the point of your Sword over against your shoulder, your arm not so much extended, your left hand in level with your eye, your left shoulder more turn'd, your
head upright, your eye fixed,— Advance. Your body steady; one, two, as you were, redouble, your foot fixt, a leap back— When you make a thrust you must let your sword move before your body: One, two; come Sir, take me in tierce, home, home, advance, your body steady, advance, thrust: one, two, as you were, redouble, a leap back, to your guard Sir, to your guard.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Euh, euh— well now for the trick—

div.stage: Tr. hits him 2 or 3 pushes with his foile, as he cryes to your guard.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, it is too rare to show to every one, if you please let the Boy depart the room, your man may stay, but he must swear secresie.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Do you hear?—

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Begar me be no Englishman, to tell all dat me see or know.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Here, take you my Foile— come, suppose I was to fight against you two, I would kill you both.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Both!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Both.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh dat be te brag— Alloon— mort bleu.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To your postures— now—

div.stage: Trick. draws his sword, Jaq. throws down his Foile.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Begar and so me tink, we two foiles against your sword— no— no— pardonnè moy—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, now— 'tis in the scabbard.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Kill me now and you can.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To your postures then— so— look to your hits.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Come—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah, ah, what art— avant a Ghost— there—

div.stage: Trick. Looks as affrighted, they both look behind them, he gives each a good push with his sword.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Euh—

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Euh—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now had you bin both kil'd or no?— there's a trick for you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I, but I warrant you I would not be killed so a second time.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come to your postures again, each fix his eye on the point of his sword; now suppose your enemy was before you, you a first, and he your second.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Nay, we'l look to our selves, now we know your tricks.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Suppose I was placed by your enemies in a hedge behind to make a noyse, that might cause you to look back.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: No, no, we no look back.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I wager a crown with you Master Iorden, you look back, tho' you are forewarned.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Done with me too.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Done: well, prepare— so, ho, ho, ho, not yet— lo, ho— lo, ho— not yet— well, I shall have you anon.

div.stage: Trick. Hallows, and takes Jord. cloaths.
They stand still in their postures.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Your Daughter Master Iorden—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I hear you Sir.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Is so well convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, no, this wont do.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Yes Sir, she'l do any thing, I have so convinc'd her of Sir Simon's good qualities, and your fatherly care,—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well Sir, I care not, I care not.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: That she is now extreamly rejoyced, and will be glad to see him come.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O this trick wo'nt do.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: No, no, we no lose te crown, I'l lay one more.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: There's some trick in't, they not so much as stir. What mean you, are ye both betwitcht?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, is he so cunning, to set you on to make us look back.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: He! what he? here is neither he nor she besides my self, and you two.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, no body!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Yes, here comes Mistris Lucia▪

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh ho Maitre Iordan you look back, you lose your money— ha, no body here?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Who do you look for?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The Fencing-Master.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He is not here—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I saw him go out in great hast.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Sir Simon will be here before you are dressed.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Give me my cloaths and dress me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Cloaths! here be no cloaths; oh dam English trick, te Rogue steal all your cloaths.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha! my Sute gone?—

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Gone, Mounsieur, gone—

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Did he take 'em?—

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Me say▪ nothing, me swear no to tell te secret.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Sir, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He told you indeed, he'd teach you a trick to undo all you fenc'd with.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ha, ha, dere be te jest o' te trick!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I had not car'd a straw had but my Mistris seen't before it went.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Well Sir, let not this put you out of humour.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No Sir, I am more a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I'l after the thief, and see if I can recover your Sute.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: If it is gone, farewel it, I have learnt a good trick by the bargain, I'l e'n put on some of my other Sutes, and stay till my Son-in-Law comes. Master Iack get the Sute ready I wore yesterday.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You see Sir what comes of your Fencing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: My fencing I see sticks in your stomach: but I'l convince you presently. Take this Foile: now for demonstration;
sp.stage: Jord. Takes the Foiles, puts one into Lucias hand.
sp.p: When you make a thrust in Quart, it is but to do so, when in Tierce, so: see there a sure way never to be kill'd; and is not this something think you, to know what a man has to trust to when he goes to fight his enemy? Come make a thrust now, that you may see the manner on't.
sp.stage: Lucia thrusts at Jorden, and pushes him five or six times; he gives back.
sp.p: Euh, euh, euh— houh— hold, what's the Devil in the Wench?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Did not you bid me thrust? now Sir what think you of your skill?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, but you made a thrust in tierce, when you should have made a thrust in quart, and was so hasty, you'd not give a man time to purrey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You see what your fencing signifies.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Go get you to Mrs. Marina's— I see what my pains signifie in indeavouring to make you wiser. It has been well observed,

lg.l: To conquer Armies is not so hard to man,
As to o'ercome the ignorance in Woman.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: HOw these visions of gallantry, and capritives of gentility still dance in my fathers fancy!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His madness will undo us; me he'l marry to one I ne'er shall love; you he will disinherit, and marry again to get a Son that shall be a gentleman to succeed him in what will be your right.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I lament not so much he should marry, as that Marina should be his wife; nor that he should deprive me of his estate, as of her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do you then love Marina?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I do, and ever shall. She did admit my addresses till my Father's pretensions interrupted the course of my love; her father, poor Knight, is old and decrepid, has but a very slender fortune, and is glad of this occasion to dispose of his daughter to a man of estate.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Does Marina approve of my Fathers suit?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p:
She is yet scarce well acquainted with it; but
when she shall, I fear her obedience may dispose her will, for her father will be very urgent, being he can give her but little while he lives.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I pitty your condition: without her you'l be unhappy, and with her you'l be miserable, unless my father would settle some part of his estate on you.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Two thousand pounds a year his folly throws away, and yet his hand is shut to me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yet I observe you have always plenty of money.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I have a revenue coming in you know not of: I keep a Journey-man at work continually. The profits of the last half year came to five hundred pounds, which by gaming at the Groom-porters I have doubled.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How found you out the secret?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Necessity is the Mother of Invention. Love made me sensible of my wants, and wants which whet men wits to do ill, taught me the means.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is it then an unlawful course?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Strangers when they hear of it may blame me, but all that know my condition, and my fathers humour, will excuse my dealing. But here comes your Lover.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Madam, you have seen the first part of our intreague: this is that Fencer who gave your father so home a thrust this Morning.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What, Mr. Trickmore!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, out of pitty I have sent him his Suit again, for now the hour of Sir Simons absence being exspired, Mr. Iorden will expect to see him at his own house, and you shall see another tryal of Skill by way of prevention.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
At the Inn in bed. I had notice this morning he was sending to advertise your father of his arrival; I dog'd the Messenger to know the result of his message, resolving to act as occasion required. At the door I o'ertook his Fencing-Master: And he being my old acquaintance, I made known to him my design, and obtain'd his consent to go in's place,
and pass for his Usher: And this I did to prevent his journey to Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: But shou'd Sir Simon get abroad before you return to the Inn.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: There is one at his heels will do his work: My fellow Mounteback alias Doctor Cureal.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray what manner of man is this Knight for a Lover?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: For his Figure it is beyond expression, ridicule enough.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: What brains has he?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No more than our purpose requires. I'l tell you in what a pleasant posture I found him when I got to the Inn, last night. A servant chanc'd to leave open the door of the Room where he was at supper; looking in, I saw him sit at table with his Hostess, who was a notable fat burley Dame; he not being well after his journey, bespoak a Sack-posset, and invited her to the eating of it.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: So, but as to his posture,

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Twas thus. One leg with a slipper at the end of it (and that no very cleanly one) was laid upon one corner of the Table, the other in her lap, his left arm about her neck, embracing: in this manner he sat for some time, telling her the occasion of his coming to Town; that it was love▪ that his Mistress was such a one (naming you, Madam). His hostess to gratifie the relation he had made her, drank your health to him in the posset, he went to pledge it, but was taken in the middle of his draught with a coughing and sneezing, which broak out with such a violence, that all he had drank flew out at his nose and mouth into his Land-ladies face; she making a start from her chair threw him backward, he keeps his hold, draws her after him; down comes she, the posset between 'em, and her coats over 'em. A terrible out-cry there was, and I ran in amongst the rest to help: when with much ado we had found the way to take her off the right end upward, there we saw Sir Simon lying half drown'd in posset, and half smother'd with Petty coats.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: A very pleasant Relation.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: At last we got him up, but you wou'd have laugh'd to have seen how like Rogue and Whore they lookt, that had stood i'th' Pillory and been pelted with all the rotten eggs in the Parish.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Alas poor Lover.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You must think the bed was the next place after this. But yonder comes my setter, our game is not far off.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: So ho, put your selves into a posture to receive the enemy, he's marching towards us.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Where have you left him?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Coming along that street with a clutter of people about him, as if he was some monster newly come from the Desarts of Arabia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is he so remarkable to be taken notice off?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You'l see anon with what an air Nature has design'd him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: See, yonder he comes.

div.stage: Enter Sir Simon with people and boys about him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Goodness, how he is hung together!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: These that haunt him, are some unlucky Prentices, whom I advised of his coming this way, on purpose that their rudeness shou'd give me an occasion to do him some piece of service which might endear me to him.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Madam, I must not yet be seen by him, let us retire, and I'l give you instructions how to demean your self to your father, if in spight of all our endeavours he should come to the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Sir▪ Sim.
sp.p:
Very pretty, as I live; what's the matter? what wou'd you have? in my conscience the Devil's in the Town, and has possess'd all the people: Why, what a Devil ails ye all? cannot a man go along the streets without a Regiment of fools at his heels? What do you laugh at now? ye had more need go look after your wives at home, lest they make ye Monsters to be stared at; I believe I shall laugh at some of you before I leave the Town; and hau, hau, hau, too, the
devil take me if I do not give the next I see laugh a douce o'th' chops.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter here gentlemen? what mean ye? who have ye got here? have ye nothing else to do but run staring and gaping after a gentleman, as if ye were all out of your wits?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Here is a man has some reason in him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What is your business? what do ye snear at?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye, aye; at what, at what?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Do ye see any thing about him that is ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye, have I?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Is he not like other people?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye, have I horns upon my head as some of you? or am I cloven footed?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Go, go home, and learn better breeding.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: That's good counsel, and take it y'ad best.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The Gentleman is a Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The heir of an honourable Family:

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: His Ancesters deserv'd well of his Country.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And he no less.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: His behaviour challenges respect.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He is one of singular, parts.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He has been a Traveller.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye, marry have I.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He honours the Town with his presence.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: An understanding fellow this, I believe he's well bred.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He is not a person to be affronted and laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, they are mistaken in their man if they think so.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: If ye go not about your business, I will handle some of ye without mittens: go, be gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Sir, I am most hugeously obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I am troubled, Sir, to see such a person as you treated so rudely, and I ask your pardon for the whole Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, I had the honour to lodge in the same Inn with you last night, when I understood by your servant who you was, I had a great presumption to do you some piece of service—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What does this fellow expect now? Money?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And it was my good fortune to pass by the door of your Room where you was at supper, just as the out-cry was, and these hands had the honour to disengage you from being smother'd by the gentlewoman of the house, when you was overthrown by that unlucky accident, and your Hostess whelm'd over you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Was you there then?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I was, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I was so blinded with Sack-posset I could not see my deliverers.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I am glad I am again so happy to do you another piece of service.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I must give him something. Sir, pray let me requite your services with a piece of gold.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: By no means, Sir, I am not covetous of any thing but to do you service; pray put it up again. I have conceived a great inclination to serve you, and the honour shall be the only reward.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: An honest fellow this. Well Sir, I remain behind-hand with you in courtesies.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Pray let me kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: In my life I never met with such a civil fellow.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your physiognomy takes me extreamly.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I see much gallantry in it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Something very taking.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Manly and brave.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah ha.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Frank and generous.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I swear to you I am wholly engaged to serve you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I find it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: If I had the honour to be known to you, you'd say I was a man very sincere.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: An utter enemy to knavery.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I believe it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And one that is not capable to disguise his thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Plain dealing is a Jewel.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And I use it; yet in spight of the fag end of the Proverb am no beggar.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Ha! who is this I see? Sir Simon Softhead! I am ravisht to see you; Oh what a joy I feel at sight of you! What it seems you scarce know me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Sir Simon is your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Out of sight out of mind I see: but is't possible six or seven years should blot me out of your memory? It's strange that in so short a time you should forget one that professes himself the greatest friend and servant to the family of the Soft-heads of any man breathing.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh pray pardon me there— Faith I know him not.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: There is scarce one of that Family that I do not know as well as I know you, when I lived at Berry, there was no doing without me, I was always amongst 'em, I had the honour to see you there almost every day.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You shall excuse me, Sir, 'twas I received the honour— I never saw his face before.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You cannot call me to mind yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Pray excuse me for that.— I know not who it is, not I.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Don't you remember we went often together to drink?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: O Yes.— But let me be hang'd if I remember any thing like it.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: How do you call the little witty Knave that used to make us so welcome at his house?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, little Iohn.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Right, we went often thither to be merry: but what is become of his pretty daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He had ne'er a daughter.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: He ne'er a daughter! What not a witty little baggage you us'd to run after to kiss from one room to another?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, I know where abouts you are now, you mean, I warrant you, little Peggy.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Aye, Peggy, by the same token was her name.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She was George Goodale's Daughter at the Rose. Why, she's marryed.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Is She? Pray how do you call the place at Berry, where they us'd to walk?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, the Green.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Directly, 'twas there I passed so many hours of delight in your good company: You do not remember this?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I not remember't? Not in the least: if I do, I wish the Devil fetch me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: There are a hundred of these things a man forgets.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Let us embrace then, and renew our ancient amity.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: See now there is a man that loves you cordially.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Pray tell me some news of your family, Sir Simon: how does that Gentleman— your— he that is such an honest good man?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: My Brother-in-Law, the Justice of Peace?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The same, the same.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Why, he is very well.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I am very glad, I assure you; and he that's of so good an humour, the Gentleman,— your—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What my cousin Small-brain?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Aye, Mr. Small-brain,— that I should forget his name! to see how quickly things run out of a man's head. But pray how does he do?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He keeps his old humour, always merry and jocund.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Troth you tell me good news. And pray Sir Simon how does your Uncle, the—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: My Uncle? I have no Uncle.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: No? but you had at that time perhaps.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, only an Aunt.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis her I mean: The Lady your Aunt, pray how does she?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She has been dead these six years.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Indeed, I heard so, now I think on't, presently after I left the Country: Well, rest her soul, she was as good a Gentlewoman as lived.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: We had also a Nephew that dyed of the small Pox.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Oh what pitty it was, he was a hopeful young man.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Did you know him?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Know him? he was a comely proper young Youth.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Not very proper.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Yes, for his age.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh yes, for his age.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: If he was your Nephew, that I mean, he was the Son of your Sister and Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Right, he was so.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: 'Twas the same.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He knows all my Relations.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He knows you better than you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I hope I shall oblige you to make my house your home while you stay in Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I am obliged to be at my Father-in-Laws.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Are you married then, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, but all's agreed on.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: But however you shall dine with me to day.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I have sent▪ Mr. Iorden word I was coming, and he'l expect me I know at dinner.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p:
Mr. Iorden then is your Father-in-Law: Well, well, that shall not hinder my design, he is my Neighbour
and intimate friend, we are as it were brothers▪

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You shall stay, and I'l send for him to dinner too.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: 'Twill be a trouble, and—

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: No excuse Sir Simon, for by my soul you shall; I have sworn it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Since he so importunes you, accept it; he has sworn it, and 'twill not be courteous to refuse him now.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Where are your Servants, and Portmanteau?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Truly my coming was in great haste▪, and for expedition, I left all but one man behind, and he is at the Inn where the Coach lyes.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir Simon, I will, if you please, wait on you to the Inn where your man stays, and then help you to find this Gentleman's house. Pray wher's abouts is it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: This is the house.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: We'l be with you in a trice.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I will in, and give orders for your reception; you shall find me here at your return.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I'l not fail to trouble you.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I'l wait your coming with impatience.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He has the carriage of a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah, ha, he, a good jest, a good jest i▪ faith.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What occcasions your mirth?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, why I don't know that I ever saw any such man before in my life.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, as I live, not I.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, Sir, no matter, he knows you.

div.stage: Enter Young Jorden and Cureal, as from over-hearing.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: So, he has trussed his Quarrey: how do you like Sir Simon for a womans man?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Sure there is no woman in the world so necessitated to venture on him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O many.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p:
Not she that wears a stiff Busk to keep down a
great belly, and is to pass for a Maid still; or she that is forc'd to come to a Play in a Vizard-Mask to pick up a gallant to give her a Supper.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Nay, not she that has lived to be a stale Maid, and is convinc'd by her own imperfections that she shall never know any pleasure, but what her own art and industry can create, but would think her self cast away on him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O, Sir, a Country Knight will down with many Court and City Ladies, 'tis a great convenience to have a husband that is blind in his reason, and is not clear enough sighted in's understanding to see the shadow his horns cast.

div.stage: Enter Jorden on one side, a Foot-boy on the other, and gives Cureal a Letter, who reads it.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Here is the Court Doctor come, I believe for some more of your money.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Speak of him with respect, he is a person of great importance, he talks to the King and Nobles at Court as familiarly as I to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Yes, he wants neither confidence nor impudence.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He does me the honour to come often to me; is't not an honour▪ think you, to be visited by one of the Kings Physicians, and a Favourite too as he is?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: He is the best paid for his visits to you of any Doctor in Town, let him visit Lord, Duke, or King.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He does me the honour to let me lend him a sum of money now and then: Can I do less than lend it to a man that is in favour at Court, and calls me his friend?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What courtesies does he do you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: More than you are aware of.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Yes, he does you the favour to borrow money of you rather than of any body else.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye, and more than so, he had rather borrow ten times of me than once of any other man living; and does it so Courtly and Gentleman like.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: And pays it so frankly, and with so good a grace.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: When I please he will.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What security does he give you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: His word▪ as he is a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: You'l have it again without doubt, that is security enough.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He shall command what he will.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: No doubt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Tell your Lady I'l wait on her immediately.
My dear friend Mr. Iorden how do you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, to do you service.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Y'are very modish and fine in this habit, you exceed all the young Gallants at Court.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hay, hay.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Turn you— Gallant all over.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pretty well: e'en as the Taylor pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I know not what is the matter Mr. Iorden, I am never so well as when I am with you, you are the man of all the world I most esteem and love, I was speaking of you this morning to the King as I stood by his bed-side.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: To the King! You did me a great honour I vow.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir? pray put on—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I know my respect to you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Fie Mr. Iorden, no ceremony among friends.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You must, Sir, by all means: you are my friend.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I protest I will not, till you are cover'd.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I had rather be uncivil than troublesome.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Well, Sir, as I was saying, I spoke of you to the King▪ and he has given order the Patent be made, and commands me to bring you to him, and he'l confer on you the honour of Knighthood; he shewed much joy and willingness when I told him, and was much pleased when I mentioned you to him.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am extreamly beholden to him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Name what day I shall wait on you to kiss his Majesties hand, and I'l advise you if he will be at leasure.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir; as soon as you please: to day I cannot, but to morrow—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: To morrow I cannot neither▪ Well▪ let it alone a day or two till the Patent is ready for the Seal.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I wou'd have it so soon as I could.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I might get it done to day peradventure, if I had the money ready to give in fees, and something a little extraordinary, and so forth as you know.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What will do?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Let me have two hundred pounds, and for what is over I'l be accountable.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have that sum here in gold.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It may be, less may do.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, Sir, pray take purse and all.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: So, leave it to my management, this will hasten the dispatch. But now Mr. Iorden, Sir Ionathan Iorden that shortly will be: As to my affairs, you know I stand indebted to you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A few dribbling sums, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And you lent 'em me very frankly, and with a great deal of generosity, and much like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Y'are pleas'd to say so, Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But I know how to receive kindnesses, and to make returns according to the merits of the person that obliges me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No man better.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Therefore pray let's see how our accounts stand.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: They are down here in my Table-book.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I am a man that love to acquit my self of all obligations as soon—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: See the Memorandum.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You have set it all down?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pray read.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Lent the second time I saw you one hundred Guinneys.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Another time fifty.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Lent for a certain occasion which you did not tell me, one hundred and fifty.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Did I not? that I should conceal any thing from my friend.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No matter, Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It looks like mistrust which is a wrong to friendship.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O Lord, Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I am so asham'd, for I dare trust my soul with you. I borrowed it, Mr. Iorden, to lend a person of Quality, whom I imployed to introduce me to the King, and recommend me to his particular favour, that I might be able to do you service in your affairs.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O was it so, then that debt is as it were paid, I'l cross it out.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: By no means, Mr. Iorden, you shall have it▪ or I vow—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, Sir, as you please.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I vow, I wou'd ne'er have borrowed any of you again as long as I had lived. But proceed.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Another time, one hundred.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O that was to send into France to my wife to bring her over; but the Queen wou'd not part with her then, and since she is fallen sick.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Alas.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But pretty well recovered.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: These four sums make up four hundred Guinneys.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Just as can be.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A very good account; put down two hundred Guinneys more, which I will borrow of you now, and then it will be just six hundred; that is, if it will be no inconvenience to you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Euh, not in the least.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It is to make up a sum of two thousand pounds which I am about to lay out in houses I have bought: but if it will incommode you, I can have it elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O by no means.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You need but tell me if it will be any trouble.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, that you will think so!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
I know some will be glad of the occasion to serve me; but these are favours only to be ask'd of special friends: And
I thought you being my most esteem'd friend, would take it ill if you should come to hear of it, that I did not ask you first.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It is a great honour, and you much oblige me in so freely giving me occasion to serve you. I'l go fetch it instantly.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Is he gone for the money?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You'l be two hundred pieces richer if he live but to come out again.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Did you find him easie?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: As a single-soaled-Shooe, he did not want much drawing on, the hopes of Knighthood make him as loving.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: You baited your hook well.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: We'l still keep him in play, that we may have t'other pluck at his purse-strings.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I wish you cou'd as successfully wheadle him out of Marina for me.

sp.speaker: Cur▪
sp.p: If your Mistress had but half so good an opinion of you as he has of me.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: She has often admitted my courtship, and by that I guess she does not wish me ill. But could you not invent a way to break off my Fathers correspondence with the old Knight her Father, and especially prevent his treating her to day? his courtship is now but beginning to her▪

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: By no means▪ to put him by, were to make you lose many opportunities of seeing and discoursing with her: Conceal your love, and you'l find, not to discourage his hopes will be to your advantage; Love, in time, will teach her to transgress that blind obedience which keeps her in subjection.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I hear him returning, I'l march off.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: When we have got the money, we'l consult of your Love.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Look you Mr. Doctor, there are three hundred Guinneys.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Three hundred?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: True, you ask'd but for two, but I count the two no courtesie; the other hundred you shall give me leave to lend you without being ask'd, that I may be satisfied, I have done something may express my kindness to you.

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.p: Well, Mr. Iorden, you are the most a Gentleman for your time I ever saw in my life; this is the most heroical Act! Indeed I did not think it possible to have found out a way to oblige a friend at such a high rate.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O, Sir, I am behind hand with you as to that.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I am so ashamed, I know not how to imitate your generosity, and I have such a zeal to do you some piece of service. When will you and your daughter Mrs. Lucia come to a Ball at Court, and I'l carry you in, and place you among persons of Quality?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The next time there is one, we'l both come.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: There will be one very suddenly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, Mrs. Lucia bid me acquaint you she is returned.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Has she brought Mrs. Marina?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: There is a Lady with her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Tell her I am coming; bid her have her into the dining Room, and let all things be in readiness.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sir, I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You shall walk in and take part of a Collation.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I am sent for to a Lady of great Quality, who writes me word, I must not fall to visit her.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But Mrs. Marina is come, you must needs go in and see my Mistress first.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I have so natural a kindness for you, I can refuse you nothing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You oblige me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Madam, regard my Brothers youth, and sorrow, it is for you he sighs, and languishes; and tho▪ you cannot cure, yet ease his pain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Were I permitted, dearest Lucia, to pursue my own inclinations, he should not unregarded grieve; but I am not at my one dispose: imagine your self in my condition, and tell me how you wou'd act on this occasion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Alas! I am subject to the same misfortune, and therefore already qualified to be your Counsellor, and be assured I give no advice but what I take my self.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do you then encourage your Lover?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To the utmost of my power.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It will be too difficult for me on the sudden, for I have not yet pass'd my first blushes, tho' I receiv'd from him proofs of his love, I gave him not any acknowledgements of mine.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Nor wou'd I now put you to the trouble of inventing such nice and wary words as Virgins use, when first they give encouragements to their Lover: let me interpret it from your actions, receive this trifle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Start not, Madam, he but presents you with a Ring of a small value, if you will not receive it from his hands, take it from mine: but wear it for his sake.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: And with it take my heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If I do more than I ought, yours, Madam, be the blame.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: But fair Marina, if your Father will not give consent I marry you—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I will declare to him my real inclinations.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: But if he prove averse, and unalterable?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'l threaten to fly beyond Sea to a Nunnery, and for ever to exclude my self from the world.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: But if in spight of all, he will force you to a Marriage?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me say?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: That, which I fain would hear you say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: That which one wou'd say, who loves well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p:
That nothing shou'd compel you, and that against
all endeavours of your Father to the contrary you wou'd promise to be mine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Content your self with what I have already said and done, and attempt not to know the future resolutions of my heart, nor trouble your self with apprehensions of extremities which may never happen, or if they do, suffer me to govern my self at all times according to the present state of affairs.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Madam, a little further I pray.

div.stage: Jorden having made two reverences, finds himself too near to make the third, he shoves her back from him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, I?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: One step back, and please you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How Sir? a little retreit to make room for the third.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden, Madam, understands behaviour, and with what respect to approach a Lady.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Madamoiselle, I beg pardon for my son.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I saw him give you a buss les maines.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I confess 'twas a civility too humble.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, he's not a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: In all things.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Excuse moy; his Mother was but a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He's well behaved.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: His deport is but so, so, his gard is pretty jauntee, and his garniture not much amiss, but he wants a bon mein; and, Madam, I will make it my devoir to retreive what has been amiss.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nothing pass'd, but what was extream well.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am ravish'd to hear you say so.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Sir, the Lady will be weary with standing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pray repose you at the Table, here's a small Collation to divert you. Mr. Doctor, will you please to sit? Madam, you see how poorly I regaul you,
sp.stage: They all sit down at Table.
sp.p: I ought to make an harrangue to excuse it, but I hope you'l pardon my unpreparedness.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your treat is noble.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Madam, pray chuse where most you like.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Boy, bid the Musick give us a touch of their Harmonie. Is here any thing, Madam, appears agreeable to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Every thing, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Fall too then: Sa, sa.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Without sans complement.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I use not any.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pray taste that Ragoust. Ah, what a pretty bells mains has this Lady, Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Admirable white, and well shaped.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Fill me a glass of wine: so the same to this Lady, and to every one round.

div.stage: Enter two men, and one woman in the midst who sing.

lg.l: Come Phyllis thy singer to begin the go round:
How the glass in thy hand with charms does abound!
You and the wine to each other lend arms,
And I find that my love
Does for either improve,
For that does redouble as you double your charms.
'Twixt him, you and me, 'twixt him, you and me,
To love let us vow, and vow constancie.
Your lips to the wine do give a new relish,
And that when you drink your mouth does embellish;
Whilst this I behold, my desires get strength,
Both with that and with you
More enamor'd I grow.
With love and with wine, I am tipsie at length.
'Twixt him, you and me, 'twixt him, you and me,
To love let us vow, and vow constancie.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hai, allons: The Hat, chappeaux bas: this Ladies health to you, Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Look you, Sir: I do you reason.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: So, 'tis gone round; 'tis with you, Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, my service to you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How do you approve of the frolick, Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Very pretty, and apt to the purpose; Love and Wine, Mr. Iorden, should go hand in hand.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Doctor, if Mrs. Marina would be as favourable to pledge in one as the other.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: She is so charming, she can do nothing but oblige, Mr. Iorden, pray give me leave to begin a health.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: With all my heart: Fill round.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And let's have t'other Song to encourage us.

lg.l: Let's drink, dear friends, let's drink,
The time flyes fast away,
And we no leisure have to think,
Then let's make use on't whilst we may.
When the black Lake we have pass'd,
Adieu to Wine, to Love and Pleasure;
To drink, to drink, let us make haste;
To drink we always sha'nt have leisure.
Let's love, let's drink whilst we have breath;
Nor love, nor drink is after death.
Disputing leave to Sotts
That are more grave than wise:
What's life's true bliss our learning lyes
In the bottom of the pots.
Great riches, knowledge, and great fame,
Ease not the troubl'd mind of care;
But rather more increase the same;
But we by drinking eur'd are.
'Tis only wine can do the feat:
Wine makes our happiness compleat.
Drink, drink, drink off your wine, turn, turn, turn up your glass,
Turn it up, turn it up; till we cry, let it pass, let it pass.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Very fine i'faith: Now, Mr. Iorden, to this Ladie's best inclinations, and long may they live in favour of whom this Lady wears this fine Ring.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Courage: so, and long may he live.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Not a word more of the Ring, you'l make a discovery.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord. Luc.
sp.p: Long may he live, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How, Madam, do you approve their singing?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It was not amiss, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: In my opinion 'tis admirable.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It was indeed most ravishing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, cou'd we but as easie ravish your heart.
