sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, my service to you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Sarrah, give me that Glass as it is.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Observe, Madam; Mr. Iorden drinks just where your lip has been, and all this while eats nothing but what your fingers have touch'd. Oh the little Arts of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, I am ignorant of your meaning.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l take t'other glass, and then Mr. Doctor—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l tell her my mind more plainly.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But have a care what you do, you must not blurt all out at once, Maids are shie.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But I intend to show my self a man of courage, and boldly to declare my Amour.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, that is City-courtship; but now you are to make love Ala mode, to act like a Gentleman, Ala negligence, with a certain kind of gallantry that obliges more than words: Entertainments, Songs, Dances and Musick are preparatives.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Must I not speak to her?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
Your treat this time speaks enough; this lays an obligation;
obligations beget respect, respect begets love, love begets marrying, and marrying begets children.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I have a damnable itching to tell her my mind; but since obligations beget so to the end of the Chapter, I'l let her know how much she is beholden to me. That Ring Madam—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I shall be disgrac'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Father says, becomes your hand.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Cost a good sum of money.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how much do you think it cost?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It cost fifty pounds.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I believe it might.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Father, Madam, has skill in Jewels.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: 'Tis well worth your wearing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am not much affected with Jewels, but I have a particular reason to wear this.
You shall see how prettily I'l wheadle her to tell me she loves me.] Why, Madam? because it was given you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir, for the sake of the Giver.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Madam, this small present deserves not so great an honour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Excuse me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You set too great a value on it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I rate it according to the merit of the person that presented it.
Lo you there.] That person is very much your humble servant, and wishes it was much better for your sake.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I think, Sir, he does not wish me ill.
Look you again.] When you know him better you will say so; he loves you extreamly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis likely he may, but men know how to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But he, Madam, the least of any one in the world.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am glad you confirm me in my good opinion; but I wonder to hear this from you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: The Lady wonders to hear you commend your self so.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Madam, if my over-forwardness offends you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: On the contrary it pleases me extreamly to hear you speak well of him.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It is my near concern gives me the occasion; but truly I never knew any of the Iordens not Gentlemen in the point of Love, tho' I speak it that should not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I did not think you had known so many as I perceive you do.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Now Sister all comes out.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: If I did not, Madam, who shou'd?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Since our Love is no longer a secret as I thought it had been, and you approv't, I hope by your means my Father may be enclined.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O, I had got his consent before: and this design of my daughters bringing you hither was a plot laid to gain a good opportunity to court you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I was so well inclin'd before, I could not long forbear the acknowledgement, tho' I cannot but blush to own I am so soon o'er-come.
Is not this a rare wheedle Mr. Doctor?] How glad am I to hear this, for in truth I think courtship the most troublesome thing in the world.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yet, Sir, you must use it with my Father.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Let me alone to deal with him, we'l send for a Parson, and the marriage shall be concluded to night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Alas, I know my Father will obstruct our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Madam, take my word for it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if he can be won to consent to it.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Lord! you are so hard of belief.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, he guessed once at our love, and did not then seem displeas'd; but I believe he has since design'd me for some other; for of late he has strictly charg'd me to the contrary; he told me himself he had provided one wou'd be a sitter match for me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, Madam, to clear all doubts, I'l e'ne wait on you home, and you shall soon hear what he says. Mr. Iack, give me my Sword and belt.

sp.speaker: Luc!
sp.p: Madam, pray let me set this curle right for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A little this way. Ah, Madam, you are unhappily run into a mistake: my Father knows not of my brothers love for you, and himself is the man your Father has found out to be your husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What good luck have I to dispatch so great an affair in so short a time: I was wooing my first wife at least a year; But to see how obliging a Gentlewoman is over a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You must resolve to stand to the brunt of 't, but conceal my Brothers being your Lover.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'l indeavour't, and frame some excuse for what I said.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Come, Madam. How your hand trembles?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My heart misgives me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Allons courage, your Father will consent, I warrant you. Lucy, stay you at home to receive Sir Simon: I much wonder he comes not yet; but when he does send me word.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Let the Musick stay till night; and bid them practise their Dialogue; we cannot stay to have it now, but it will serve rarely well at supper, and will be as good for a wedding as an Epithilamium. Mr. Doctor, your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sir, I'l wait on you out, for I must be going too. Madam, I am going to meet your Lover. Mr. Iorden take heart, things may yet go well.

div.stage: Exeunt Iorden Singing, How happy a lover am I, Marina, Cureal. While I sigh not for Phyllis in vain,

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: And I how unhappy!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All may go well yet, ever hope the best.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I cannot hope my love should not be discovered.

lg.l: Brother, think on Marinas Love, you'l find
Sufficent ground for hope whilst she proves kind.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: BEsure you look well to him; keep all the doors shut and lock'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: When he is once in Lobs-pound, he shall not easily escape.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Here he comes.— Sir Simon, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You see I make bold.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You honour my house. But where is the Gentleman that was to show you the way?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He left me but just now, he showed me the house, and begg'd leave for an hour.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I shou'd have been glad he had been here to bear you company till my return: I'l step cross the street and fetch Mr. Iorden to you. But see here a person into whose hands I commend you, he will treat you with all courtesie possible.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: My profession obliges me, and 'tis enough you command my care.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: This is the Steward of's house: He must be a person of quality.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yes, I assure you, I'l treat Sir Simon according to the method and rules of Art.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh pray make no ceremony, I beseech you, treat me as a friend, let me be no trouble.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Such an imploy is not my trouble but delight.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Here, Sir, is ten pounds advance of what I promis'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, I understand not wherefore you shou'd put your self to charge for me: Pray, Sir, let him not buy any thing extraordinary, but let me partake of the usual entertainment of your Family.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, give me leave: it is not for what you imagine.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Not for provision, Sir; a spare dyet is wholesome; much meat sends up fumes from the stomach to the head, and that is very hurtful for the brain, especially to one that is a little disordered.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He talks learnedly. But I befeech you, Sir, let me fare like a friend, and not a stranger.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: 'Tis that I intend: I pray, Sir, excuse the incivility I commit in leaving you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you leave me in good company.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It is a great honour to me, Sir, to be chosen one to do you service.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I am your servant.

div.stage: Enter Trickmore in a Physicians habit.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: See there an able man, my great friend, with whom I will consult the manner how to treat you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Once more I request you to make no such ceremony, I am a man content with ordinary usage.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come, set chairs here. Sir, please you take that place.

div.stage: Sir Simon sits down in the middle chair which is biggest, and with arms, which locks him in that he cannot stir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ha, what's the meaning of this? I am fast.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: An Italian device, we meant to surprize you with a rarity.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I cannot get up.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: We can soon set you at liberty, it may be you don't sit easie.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Oh, very well, I thank you: I shou'd be loth,
were it not among friends, to be so engag'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come friend, pray draw your chair nearer. Now to our business. Give me your hand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your hand, Sir, I beseech you.

div.stage: Sir Simon gives his hands as in courtesie to friends: they feel his pulse.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, your servant, Gentlemen, your servant.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I beseech you hold still a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Have you a good stomach? do you eat well, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ay, and drink well too.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: So much the worse, this great appetition of cold and humidity is an indication of the heat and driness within. Do you sleep sound▪

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Yes, when I have eat a good Supper.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Do you dream, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Sometimes.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Of what nature are your dreams?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Why, of the nature of dreams. A Devil, what kind of entertainment is this?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: How do you go to stool, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: As others do. A plague on't, I know not what they mean by these Questions: pray let me be so bold to call for a glass of wine.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Have patience, Sir: I doubt whether it be good for you; we will begin and discourse of the thing it self, and that you may the better understand we'l dispute in English, and resolve upon your food, what meats and drinks are properest for you, and will do you the least harm.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What needs so much discourse about my eating and drinking?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Patience, Sir, you must be patient.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What a devil wou'd they be at?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I say with your permission, Sir, that our patient here present is very much assaulted, affected, afflicted, possessed, and o'ercome with this sort of folly, which is very well called Hypochondriack melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: These are Doctors, now shall I have a lecture read o'er me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, sit still.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: This Hypochondriack Melancholy proceeds from the deprav'd constitution of some part of the neather belly, and inferiour region: but particularly from the spleen. To be assured that this is his disease, you need but observe this great dulness which you see, this heaviness accompanied with fear and diffidence, signs, pathognomiques and individuals of this disease so well observed by the divine Hippocrates; this Physiognomy, these eyes, red, heavy and dull; this grisly beard, and grumness; this swarthy, tawney complexion; this constitution of body, lean, spare and haggord, rough, black and hairy; all which signs denote him to be very much o'ercome with this disease proceeding from the depravedness of the Hypochondria.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, you must sit still.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
Now I mean to touch the Therapeia, and remedies which ought to be prescribed to effect a perfect cure. First, then to remedy this Plethora, and this Cacochymia, or general depravation of humours throughout all the body; my advice is for Phlebotomy; that he bleed freely; that is to say, plentifully; first of the Basilick, then of the Cephalick vein; and if the disease prove obstinate and refractory, that a vein be opened in his forehead, and that the orifice be very large, that the thick corrupted bloud may have passage; and at the same time that he purge, deopitulate and evacuate by proper and convenient purgations; that is to say, by Cholagogues, Melanogogues, &c. But before all these, I find it meet to exhilarate his spirits with harmony resulting from Musick instrumental and vocal, with which it will not be amiss to joyn some Dancers; to the end that their motions, postures, and agility of bodies, may excite, stirr up, and quicken his spirits stupified with idleness, which occasions the thickness of his bloud, from whence proceeds the Malady: these are the Remedies I prescribe, which may be much advantag'd by some others of yours much better and more efficacious,
having by your daily practice gain'd great experience, judgement and knowledge in our Art. Dixi.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Nay, now, Sir, you must have a little longer patience to hear my Brother Doctor.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: There remains nothing for me to say to the Gentleman, but that he was a luckie man to fall into your hands, and that he is even too happy in being a fool, in that he shall experiment the efficacie and admirable virtues of these Remedies you have propounded with so much judgement: I approve of all, Manibus & pedibus descendo in tuam sententiam: All that I say is, let the number of his bleedings and purgations be odd, Numero Deus impare gaudet: To drink often clarified Whey, to bathe often, to have a strait band made with salt in it to bind upon his forehead, for salt is the emblem of wisdom; and to new whiten the walls of his chamber, to dissipate the darkness of his spirits, Album est disgregativum visùs: A gentle glister to serve for the introduction to these judicious Remedies, with which he is to be cured, and he ought to receive consolation. Heaven grant that these Remedies you mentioned may according to our intention work their effects upon your patient.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have listned to ye all this while, and I have no more patience left. What, do you sport with me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, we dont sport with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What means all this? what wou'd you with your mountebanck canting?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Good, see a Diagnostick which we wanted for the confirmation of his disease, and this may well turn to madness.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A pox on't, who am I left here with?

div.stage: He spits three or four times.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Another Diagnostick, his frequent spitting.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Let me out here, let me be gone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yet another, his unquietness, and desire to change, and shift places.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What's the matter? what a devil ayl ye? what wou'd you do with me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Cure you, according to order given.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Cure me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What a devil, I am not sick.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A very ill sign, when a sick man perceives not his own disease.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I tell you I am very well.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh, we know better than you how you do; we can see into your constitution.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I tell you I was never better since I was born.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Worse and worse, he has been a fool from his Cradle.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Let him be rul'd by us, we'l cure him, I'l warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I'l be rul'd by none of ye, ye are a couple of knaves.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: We are your Physicians, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Worse and worse, ye are the greater knaves for that. Physicians! what have I to do with Physicians? a fart for you, and your Physick too: a Caudle, Ale-berry, or a good Posset is worth all your damn'd drugs.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A hone, a hone, the man is a greater fool than we thought him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: My Father and Mother never took Physick in their lives, and they are both dead without the help of Physicians.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I wonder no longer then, that they had a son no wiser; come, let us proceed to the cure, and by the sweet exhilarating of harmony, sweeten, allay, and abate the acrimony of the spirits, which I see ready to inflame him. O here comes my Operators.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What in the Devils name is all this? are all the people in this Town mad? I never saw the like in my days, what should it mean?

div.stage: Enter two Chymists dress'd in antick habits with broad black caps on their heads, that flap down about their ears, no hair seen; Ruffs about their necks, strait bodyed doublets with long close sleeves; Spanish scant breeches, and pumps; followed by four Operators in antick dresses, singing the symphony sustain'd with a medly of strange instruments.

sp.speaker: 1 Chym.
sp.p: What ailest thee thou musing man?

sp.speaker: 2 Chym.
sp.p: What art thou melancholy?

sp.speaker: 1 Chym.
sp.p: Come let's cure him if we can.

sp.speaker: 2 Chym.
sp.p: Sadness is the greatest folly.

sp.speaker: 1 Operat.
sp.p: Let's cure this wight.

sp.speaker: 2 Operat.
sp.p: He's a gallant Knight.

sp.speaker: 3 Operat.
sp.p: 'Tis great pit-ty,

sp.speaker: 4 Operat.
sp.p: That he should dy

lg.l: Of folly,
Or of melancholy.

sp.speaker: 1 Chym.
sp.p: We to cure thy sadness come.

sp.speaker: 2 Chym.
sp.p: Mirth with us we bring along.

sp.speaker: 1 Chym.
sp.p: Throats let's clear with crying hum.

sp.speaker: 2 Chym.
sp.p: Then treat this gallant with a Song.

sp.speaker: 1 Operat.
sp.p: With Song we'l advance,

sp.speaker: 2 Operat.
sp.p: With Musick and dance;

sp.speaker: 3 Operat.
sp.p: With these we will clear him.

sp.speaker: 4 Operat.
sp.p: Then give him glisters half a dozen.

sp.speaker: 1 Operat.
sp.p: To purge away melancholy and clear him.

sp.speaker: 2 Operat.
sp.p: Then rinse his body with Canary and Sherrey.

sp.speaker: 3 Operat.
sp.p: If this will not make him merry,

sp.speaker: 4 Operat.
sp.p: 'Tis we

sp.speaker: 1 Operat.
sp.p: That be

sp.speaker: 2 and 3 Operat.
sp.p: More fools than he,

sp.speaker: 1 and 4 Operat.
sp.p: And our art will us couzen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And our art will us couzen.

lg.l: Let him that's melancholy,
Each morning when he gets up
Take of Sack a good cup:
Sing a catch, and again sup:
Sip and sing, sing and sip again and again,
Till he find the Canary doth work in his brain.
Then to dinner go, and after
Let him sit and hatch a laughter:
Sing t'other catch, take t'other cup,
Till each hath drunk his bottle up.
Thus laugh, thus quaff, thus quaff, thus laugh again & again,
Till he find the Canary doth work in his brain.
At supper let him eat
But light and little meat;
Yet trowl the cup roundly away;
But avoid foggy Ale,
And Beer new or stale:
For Wine is the liquor,
Makes the wits to grow quicker,
And each o'er his glass to tell a merry tale.
This melancholy evil
Is a sort of a Devil,
Which wine and not holy water will drive away:
Nothing is so sure,
And perfect a cure,
As wine, as mirth, and good companie:
And if ought doth lack
'Tis a pipe of Tobac— coco— coco— coco—
Which taken may be
When to bed he doth go, gogo, gogo, gogo,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come let's have him up to his Chamber, and there give him the remedies perforce, which he refuses to take here.
sp.stage: The Dance ended, Cureal and Trickmore rise from their seats.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Help to let him out of his stool of repentance.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Stay, let me take out my handkerchief to blow my nose. The Devil take ye all for Rogues.

div.stage: They let Sir Simon out of the chair, he puts his hand into his pocket, and takes out a Pistol; they start back, he runs out, they discharge their glisters, and run out after him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He is gone, gone beyond recovery, all my designs are ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A pox o'that Pistol.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A pox on you for leaving the Key in the door.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: who'd have thought—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: That you shou'd have plaid the Mountebank so long, and have no more brains in your scull.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I have a device to recover all.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He'l find out Mr. Iorden, and then—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I'l to him first, and doubt not but I'l forestal his reception for a while: And here comes Mr. Iorden as I could wish.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hold him in discourse till I come and second you in a new design.

div.stage: Enter to Cureal Mr. Jorden, Cleverwit, and Lucie.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: There was juggling in the case, Lucia, for I find it was your brother presented the Ring to her, he was the man for whose sake she wore it, therefore tell me true how he came by it?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: It may be she lost it, or laid it down somewhere, and he took it up.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How was it then? let me know.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Brother, Sir, desired that he might present it, and I, ignorant of his pretensions to Marina, gave it him.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But that thou art to be a Lady to night I wou'd beat thee for it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, I thought no harm, and judg'd it more fit for him to give it, than for me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Let me heat a reason for that, and I'l forgive thee both this and the next fault.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I imagin'd, Sir, Mrs. Marina would think my brother would be displeased at the match, as most sons are when their Fathers marry again, it being against their interest to have a new brood in the Family, and might from thence have some scruple to match with you, having children so well grown: therefore I gave him the Ring to present, that it might appear by this Act, my Brother did well approve of having her for a Mother-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: This is very rational.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, get you in again; and tell your Brother he has no way to come off with me, but utterly to renounce her, and resign her to me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I hope he will.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I thought Sir Simon would have visited your house with Lovers speed.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Something is the matter he comes not yet, and I am going to see what it is detains him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden, have you seen Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, is he come?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come! yes, Sir, and gone.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He has not been at my house.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: He has shown me a light pair of heels.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Is he come for certain to this end of the Town?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: And gone for certain?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Both for certain; and if he comes to you, let him not conclude the marriage with your daughter till he be duly prepar'd for it, and reduced to an estate of begetting children, well conditioned both in body and mind.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Nor do I know what he means.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Your Son-in-Law that is to be, was this morning put into my hands by a near relation of his that endeavours his good, to be my patient, and I must tell my friend, I do not think fit he should marry your daughter till he hath taken the remedies I am to prepare for his disease.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Has he any disease?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A most notorious one, and hard to be cured, 'tis gotten into his brain.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: What is his disease?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Folly.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, that's one Reason why I make him my Son-in-Law; for what better husband can I provide for my daughter, than one that has much honour, a great estate, and but little wit.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I'l assure you, Mr. Doctor, you may spare your drugs and labour too, for his disease is as hereditary to his Family, as his estate, and you may sooner cure him of that than of the other.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But he has another disease I have not told you off.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Another?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: One that debilitates his body as much as this his mind.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Doctors are bound to secresie.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You may tell Mr. Iorden:

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: For his Daughters sake, and because he is my friend, I will. But you must both promise to keep it secret.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Doubt not, that Gentleman is my great friend.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Pray out with it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I'l trust ye for once.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: You may.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You know, Mr. Iorden, Sir Simon has been in France.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have heard so.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: There he fell extreamly in love with a Lady. He gave her his Gold, and she as a token of her kindness gave him the Pox.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The Pox!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The Pox said you?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: No such great wonder, for most young English Gallants that go thither have the like misfortune.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The Pox his disease!

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: It is indeed the fate of most young Travellers.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Like most of 'em too he fell into the hands of an unskilful Chirurgeon, who made no perfect cure; and should he marry as he is, he either would have no children; or if he has, they will be peuling, whining, sickly things, scab'd as young Cuckows, and look like Chickens that have got the pipp.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: We see the example of it daily.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But that he is both Knight, and Baronet, he should not have my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I doubt not, but by the course I intend for him, within forty days to put his body in a good condition for procreation.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well then, I'l have him enquir'd out, he shall marry my daughter presently, lest she should hear on't▪ and be averse to the Marriage: And then Mr. Doctor and friend, I will deliver him again into your hands.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: How! let him marry your daughter before he is eured?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, Il make sure of him first; for he may dye under your hands, and then she misses the title of Lady, and the honour of having been wife to a Knight Baronet; besides, he makes her a very great joynture.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: How his folly frustrates our designs!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now is the time I must show my self a man of intrigue▪ or for ever lose the reputation I have gotten.
Gentlemen, can any of you inform me which is Doctor Cureal's house?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: That is his house, and this Gentleman is the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I am Doctor Cureal.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I have a little private business, and beg these Gentlemens leave to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden, you have not yet told me how you like your Mistress?

div.stage: Trickmore and Cureal whisper at one end of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, 'tis the prettiest charmingst Rogue—

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Her eyes are but little.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, but Mr. Cleverwit, so sparkling, so black and so piercing, they strike a man to the heart at first sight.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: She has a wide mouth.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: She has so, but so many graces about it, such pretty dimples at each corner when she smiles, and such a pair of smacking lips too.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Her stature is but low.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But yet she's well shap'd: Oh, 'tis a pretty snug Rogue, she'l lye as round—

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: She speaks very little.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, a prattling woman is worse than a Flock of Geese.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: And some conclude, a woman that wants tongue wants wit.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And she that has too much, wants Grace.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I see plain, by your excusing her, that you love her, and will have her from your son.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: If her Father order her, as I'l order my son, we shall meet in a pair of sheets.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'l acquaint my friends here with the business; and if you'l engage your word before them I'l do't.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Business of this nature should not be communicated.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: They are my special friends.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you think good to trust 'em.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden, whatever you hear, say nothing, till you have made a full discovery; here is villany plotting against you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, knavery, knavery.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ye must know friends, one Sir Simon Softhead is my Patient, whom I have to cure of a certain distemper, which will require some considerable time. Well, go you on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The said Sir Simon is come to Town to marry the Daughter of one Mr. Iorden, a rich man.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now this Sir Simon owing much money to me, and five other Merchants of Norwich, we have all his land in mortage; but we being all his Fathers Friends, and having a respect for the Son, are willing to do him all the good we can; and therefore do underhand mannage the business so, combining with the said Sir Simon, that the Mortgages and Engagements shall not appear to endamage his Marriage.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Now comes the design.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: So that Sir Simon may, besides the portion he is to have with his wife, take up of his Father-in-Law (who we hear is a mony'd man) as much money as will pay all his debts, and engage to him his land before engag'd to us.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O dainty Rascals!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And then shall your Mortgage start up and take it from him.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: So shall the Son cheat the Father-in-Law, and the Father have no remedy for it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and this may easily be done, for Mr. Iorden is but a half-witted fellow.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, is he so, Rascal?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The said Land passes already currant for the joynture, tho' mannag'd by his Brother in the Country, who is not much wiser than himself.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, this Sir Simon being also a man of a thick scull, and not so sensible of his own good, as he ought to be; I, and the other five Merchants do desire of Mr. Doctor, to perswade Sir Simon to strike up the Match, and be marryed before he enter into his course of Physick, that the design so well laid may not take wind, and miscarry by his folly and want of discretion.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And for this piece of service, your self and those other five Merchants do reward me with an hundred pounds, to be demanded the day after the marriage.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I do here before these Gentlemen promise and engage my self for the true and just payment of it, and will moreover treat these Gentlemen with a Dinner of five pound.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: How are you call'd?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: My name is William Webster, Merchant of Stuffs in Norwich.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Then, I say, William Webster of Norwich, and the rest of his Merchant Combiners are knaves, ha, ha, he, bear witness Gentlemen— ha, ha, he,—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you'l not discover, I hope.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: No, no friend, you have made discovery enough.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pray tell Sir▪ Simon, my Daughter shall not be a beggar to be a Lady; there are more Knights Baronets in the World.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Mr. Doctor, is this Mr. Iorden?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: The very man, now, I think on't.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh dire mischance!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Come, Sir, pay your hundred pound, Mr. Doctor has done your business for you— ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, Sir Simon is an undone man, and so I'l go tell him.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And when you find him, tell him too he may e'en go like a fool as he came— ha, ha, he..

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: This after-game was well plaid.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A half-witted fellow! ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: How blank will Sir Simon and the rest look when they hear this news.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I fear he is more knave than fool.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden, I am glad I have serv'd you in so important an affair; I must leave my friend to visit a Lady of great Quality that has sent for me.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: And I am heartily sorry, I cannot stay till Sir Simon comes, to see the upshot of the business, for come he will if he misses this fellow.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Your servant, Mr. Iorden.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your servant, Mr. Doctor: Your servant, Mr. Cleverwit.

div.stage: Enter to Old Jorden, Young Jorden.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, are you here? I have found out all your intrigue with Mrs. Marina, you are the man in her books, are you?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Only in that one thing I am happy.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But you must think no more of her.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Not think of her!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: It is impossible.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You must resign you interest.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: To no man living.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Not, while I have life.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: She is to be my wife.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Not with my consent.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have her Fathers good liking.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: And I have the Daughters.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: She must submit to her Father's will, and you to mine.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Love is subject to no Laws but its own; when that is in dispute, all respect to power and authority is laid aside.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I shall make you know me.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: He that loves well, dares all threats desie.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You will then be medling in my concerns.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis you meddle with mine, I lov'd her first.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And you shall quit her first.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Quit her?— never—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l force you, saucy Iack.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: You cannot.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l try that.

div.stage: Jorden offers to strike Y. Jorden. Enter to them Jaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh Maitre, Maitre Iorden, vat do you mean?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I laugh at your anger.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You shall cry at my anger.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O maitre, maitre Iorden?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O fee, fee, fader beat te great son, vat, vat be te difference? make me te judge, me pass me parol to make te reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You shall hear Mr. Iack.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: But stand you two at more great distance: So now me am to be te judge: so, hum, hum, speak te fader now: Be no dat ver just to bid te fader speak before te son.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I love Mrs. Marina, and have intentions to marry her, and my son here in spight of my teeth says he will love her.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Spit in your teet, no good fashione: he be to blame ver much.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Is't not an insolence in a son to contend with his father?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: A ver great injure.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ought he not to forbear his pretensions to shew me respect?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You have te grand reason: let me go speak to him, and stand you dere.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Well, since he hath made you judge, I am content to refer the matter to you.

div.stage: Jaques goes to Y. Jorden at the other end of the stage.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You do me te ver great honour.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p:
I was first in league with Mrs. Marina, she makes kind returns to my affection; and with tenderness receives
the offers of my love; and my father comes to disturb our peace with his pretensions.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: A ver great injure.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Is it not very unreasonable to desire she should love him against her inclination, ought he not rather to quit his design?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You have te reason, let me now speak to your fader. Have you no more to say, but dat you love te Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, I have her Father's consent, and he is utterly against my sons marrying his daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ver good.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ought she not to be obedient to her father?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh vithout doubt. Let me speak to your son. Your fader do say he has te consent of her fader.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: But I have the consent of the Daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Auh dat be ' gen te ver good reazon.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Is it not a great injustice in him to cause her father to force her to marry one she does not love?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh vithout doubt, dat be ver injuste. Now let me have te consideration how te do justice, to cause be ver difficult.
Auh, you love te Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And she do you love?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And she vill marre you?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O vat remedy? vel, stay you dere—

Vell, Sir, your Zon be no so obstinate as you do tink, he do submit to you, and say vat he did tell you, vas in his great indignation, and dat he vill give you te Maitress, provide dat you vill treat him ver vell for te future; and let him have some little part of your Estate, dat he may live like te Zon of Monsieur Iordane, and marre some Gentilwoman dat be young, handsome, and rish.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, tell him he may have any thing hereafter, and except Marina, he is at liberty to choose whom he will

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O, let me mannage te affair—

Your fader have te more discretion den you imagine, he say dat
te fashione of your discourse, and your action put him in te grand colore, and dat he vill give te consent to vat you desire, provide dat you give te promise for te future to be te ver good Zon, and render to his person te respect and submission tat one Zon ow to te fader.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: You may assure him, that granting Marina, he obliges me for ever to submit my self intirely to him, and henceforward his will shall be a law to all my actions.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh so tis affair be dispatch.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: As I could wish.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Te league be conclude:
He be content vith vat you do promise.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Oh my kind Stars be thank'd.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Now, ye may make discourse togeader agen; ye se how soon te man of discretion make te accommodation.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I am much oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Not at all vor vat me do, me be your humble serviteur.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You have done well Master Iaques: there is a reward for you.

sp.speaker: Ioq.
sp.p: Me kiss your hand Maitre Iordane.

div.stage: Enter Trickmore and Cureal to Young Jorden.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I am now Trickmore again, and ready to receive Sir Simon if he come this way: I will proceed to sow such jealousies between the Father and the Son-in-Law, that shall make 'em both draw contrary ways. Yonder he comes, be gone.

lg.l: Of folly or of melancholy,
Of folly or of melancholy.— coco— coco— coco.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What mean you by this Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: All I see seems Glisters to me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You know not what has hapned since I parted from you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, what is't?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I thought I should have been treated according to my Quality.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And well.—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: And I was left by that Gentleman in the hands of two fellows cloathed in black, Physicians I suppose they were, who set me in a trap-chair, felt my pulse, shak'd their noddles, cry'd ah! is't so? he's a fool, he's a fool: then did these two buffle-headed talkative fellows in broad-brim'd hats speak nonsence for an hour, till my patience was wearied; then entered such a consort of Musick, as if they had plaid a flourish for the entry of Devils; but were followed by half a dozen Anticks singing, and dancing with Syringes and Glisters in their hands, that they made me almost out of my wits; when with much ado by the help of a Pocket Pistol, I got from 'em, they all discharg'd at me: see, am I not all beglisterfied?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Indeed you have an odd smell about you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh my imagination is filled with 'em, every thing I see methinks is a Glister.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: How deceitful is the out-side! I thought that Gentleman the sincerest of your friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A very Rascal.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: This is one of my wonderments, is't possible there should be such knavery in the world?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I think that is the house.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: According to my promise I came, thinking to have found you there, but I have knock'd this half hour, and the Devil of any body can I make answer, the doors and windows are all shut close, as if no body was in the house.

sp.speaker: Sir. Sim.
sp.p: The Rogues thought it time to be gone. Ever since I made my escape, I have been enquiring to find out Mr. Iorden; I am told he lives in this street, and I am glad I have met with you, that you may help me to find his house.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: So, so, I smell you out, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Smell me? aye so may any body: a pox on these Rogues and their Glisters.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I mean I know your design of enquiring out Mr. Iorden, you have a months mind to his Daughter, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Yes, I come to Town on design to marry her.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To marry her?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Indeed to marrry her?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye, for what else do you think?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis another matter, and I crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What mean you by this?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Pray tell.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nothing, not I, I spoak a little too hastily.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Pray let me know what was in your mind.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It is not at all convenient.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, pray out with it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: By no means, indeed you must excuse me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Then I see you are not the man I took you for, I thought you had been my friend.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No man more.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You ought not then to conceal any thing from me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It is a matter in which is concern'd the interest of a Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: To oblige you to open your heart, take this Ring and wear it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Let me think a little whether I may do it in conscience. 'Tis a man who seeks his own good, who endeavours to provide for his Daughter, as advantagiously as he can. I ought to injure no man. These things are known truths: And then I go about to discover to a man that is ignorant of them. 'Tis forbidden to speak ill of our Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Not to interrupt you, there's Gold, by my soul you shall keep it: Now pray go on.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
But on the other side, here is a stranger he would
surprise, and one who comes with a good intent to marry his Daughter, whom he knows not, nor ever saw; a Gentleman free and curteous, for whom I have a kindness, who does me the honour to esteem me his friend; reposes confidence in me, who gives me a Ring to wear for his sake, and Gold. Well, I find I can tell you all without scruple of conscience. But I'l take care to tell you as blamelesly as I can, and to spare the person as much as may be. To tell you then, this daughter of his lives dishonestly would be too harsh; I'l find some milder term to express my meaning; to say she's gallanted is not enough, but I think it will suit well with my meaning, to say she is a naughty pack; and may serve to let you know truly what she is.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, oh, they take me then for a Coaks.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It may be she is not so bad as the talk goes, and since there are some young women that expose themselves to censure by taking too much liberty, not thinking their honour and reputation depends—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, I will not be in the Turkish fashion, and go with a crescent above my brows, I love to walk without being pointed at.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, Sir, but you are resolv'd to give 'em a visit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: On purpose to let 'em see how they are deceived.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'l wait on you to the door, have a care, she's very handsome, and beauty is a sort of witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Let me alone, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: At your return you shall find me here about.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter a Boy and Sir Simon followed by Jorden.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: BE pleased to walk in there, Sir, my Master will come presently.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Where, where is the Gentleman would speak with: me?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir, are you Mr. Iorden?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: So am I call'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: And I am Sir Simon Softhead.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: In good time.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Do you think, Mr. Iorden, we Suffolk men are fools?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And do you think, Sir Knight, that we Londoners are gulls?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Do you imagine that such a man as I am, is so put to't for a wife?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And do you believe that such a woman as my Daughter is so in want of a Husband?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am inform'd Father, Sir Simon is come: this is he without doubt, my heart tells me so; what a comely person! how well shap'd! what a bone meen, and gentile carriage he has! Oh how content I am you have made choice of such a man to be my husband.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Soft and fair, daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: How coming she is.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I would fain know, Sir Simon, what wind brings you hither?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Indeed Father I am so pleas'd with Sir Simon, he's one of the comeliest and most courtly persons!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She's on fire already: Ha 'tis a pretty little loving fool.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You know what interest you have here, Sir Simon, you need not make your self so much a stranger.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Daughter stand off, keep from him I bid you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What a liquorish baggage 'tis, she'd have me salute her.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I would fain know for what reason, and please you, you—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah my dear, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Again! the wench is mad.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Will you not permit me to express a kindness to the man you have determin'd to be my husband?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, get you up into your chamber.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me but stay and look at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah pure wheedle.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Get you in, I say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'd stay here, if you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A cunning slut, how she gleggs at me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Get you in once more, or—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I go then.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Are you not gone yet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: When is it, Sir, we are to be married?

sp.speaker: Iord
sp.p: Never: let that serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: How her chops water at me!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you have promis'd I should be his Wife.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: If I promised you, I unpromise you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She's agog for me: She sings loth to depart.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But if we will, who can hinder it?

sp.speaker: Iod.
sp.p: Why I'l hinder it, and take notice I forbid the bains. My Daughter's bewitch'd, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Well, our good Father-in-Law that was to have been, don't trouble your self, I have no such maw to your Daughter. This won't do: ha, ha, he, who put it into your head that Sir Simon Softhead was a man to buy a pigg in a poke, and wants wit enough to inform himself how squares go, and one that would so soon be drawn into the noose of
matrimony without being well assured it would be safe for his reputation, ha, ha, he, he's no such fool as you take him for, I'l assure you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I know not what you mean by this; but how came you to have such a conceit in your head, that Mr. Iorden had no more brains in's scull, and consider'd his daughters good no more, than to marry her to a man who has you know what, and was put you know where, and to you know who, to be cured against you know when?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir, I know what you mean, but that's a lye, I am as sound and as well as you, or any man living.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, well, somebody that knows somebody, told somebody, tho' that somebody must tell nobody.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: That somebody is a lying Rogue; I am a Gentleman every half inch of me, and I'l make it appear with sword in hand, I'l justifie my reputation, here, or on any ground in England.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I have a sword too in my house, am a Gentleman, and may in time too be a Knight; and will tell you here, or on any ground in England, that, what I know, I know; nor am I to be couzened with Land mortgag'd already to Norwich Merchants to pay debts, not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What mortgage, what land, what debts, what Norwich Merchants, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Come, come, dissembling won't do, all's out, I am not to be chous'd out of my money, nor wheedled to pay Creditors, no, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What Creditors, ha Sir? do you know, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Who's this with a drawn Sword against my Father, and he unarm'd? Come, Sir, make me your adversary.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Your are his Hector, are you?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I am his son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: That is more than I will be, I assure you.

sp.speaker: T. Iord.
sp.p: And will vindicate his cause with the last drop of my bloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, your servant; fare you well Bully▪ Ruffian.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I'l be so civil to wait on you to the door.

div.stage: Exit Sir Simon, Young Jorden, after him with his drawn sword, clash without.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Iorden, Mr. Iorden!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What, Mr. Doctor, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Such news, such joyful news!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I made such haste hither, I scarce have breath left to tell it you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh dear Mr. Doctor!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: The Lady I went to, when I parted from you, entreats the favour of me to recommend some Lodgings to her: now it presently came into my mind, that you have a house spacious and well furnished, fit to receive a Lady of great Quality.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What, I let Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Cur,
sp.p: O no, dear friend, you mistake me: whereupon, that you might have an occasion to court and be acquainted with this Lady, said I to her, I have a friend, a very good friend, called Mr. Iorden, at which word she started, who will do me the honour to give you, or any friend of mine an appartment in his house, and there, Madam, you will be treated very honourably, and receiv'd with much respect and gallantry.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you. But what I pray was the reason she started when she heard my name?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
At that time, Madam (said I) you seem surprised: and then she blush'd, and her colour went and came, and came and went. Then I proceded: Madam does the name offend you? I must confess (said she) I know some reason to wish I had never heard the name, nor seen the man; yet have I not so much
power not to see him again, and it was my desire the Lodging you were to provide me should be near that persons house; but pray make no more words on't, said she; then blush'd again, and turn'd away and sigh'd.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What meant all this?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, it is no riddle: what think you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I vow to you I cannot guess unless it be love.

sp.speaker: Cur:
sp.p: You'l ne'er be counted a Conjurer for telling this, tho' it is a most undoubted truth.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, Sir; and will she come?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come, Sir? she can't help it, there is no resisting the influence of our stars. Lord! Mr. Iorden, that you should have such prodigious luck.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Is she very rich?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Rich? what is she think you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A Lady.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A Lady?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A Countess.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: More.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A Marquess.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A Marchioness you meam, more, Sir, more.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A Dutchess.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: More than all that.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: More than a Dutchess? what is she then?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A Princess, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A Princess, Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mum, Mr. Iorden: ha, is nobody near? let me see: have we no listners. Aye, Mr. Iorden, a Princess, I say to you she is a Princess.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l lay my life now at last the jest of it is that her name is Princess.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: No, Sir, she is a Princess by birth, her Quality is Princess.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I knew her in hanging-sleeves, I was Physician to her Father while I was in Germany.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: She is then Daughter to one of the Princes in Germany.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Right, she is a German Princess; I taught her English when I was there, and she has since marvellously improv'd her self in our Language.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am glad she understands English.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Admirably well.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Will she come to night?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Immediately; her Coach was at her door when I came. But be sure you give her no ground to apprehend you know her Quality, for she is here incognito, and will not be known till all her train and attendants come over, which will be very suddenly; therefore what you do, you must do quickly, for then she'l be for Court.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l make good use of the opportunity.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Besides should you not declare your love till after you know her Quality, she may think it is but ambition, and that you are more enamour'd of her quality than person.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l assure you, most dear friend, and divine Doctor, I will lose no time.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Well, Sir, but pray let me not lose the title of Doctor of Physick for that of Divinty.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh, Maitre Iorden, here be te ver fine Lady in te great glass Caroach, enquire for Dr. Cureal.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: 'Tis she: Prepare, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I dare be bold, now you Mr. Doctor have felt her pulse for me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Be not too ceremonious, but▪ behave yourself as if she was but what she seems, a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Madam, this is Mr. Iorden, Master of the house, and my worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, I had like to have forgot. Madam, a little nearer, I pray.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Sir?

div.stage: Jorden runs to salute her; turns his back and goes a good way, and advances, making three congies, finds himself too far off, and beckons her to come nearer.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: One step nearer, and please you: So, you are welcome, Madam, as I may say. Oh she kisses like a Queen!

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I presume upon Mr. Doctore▪ score of friendship to give you the trouble of being your guest some few days.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Madam, it is to me a great glory to see my self so fortunate, as to be so happy to have the good luck, that you should have the bounty to do me such a grace, as to afford me the honour, to honour me with the favour of your good company. Aud that—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden, you have done well, this Lady loves not much ceremony, she knows you are a man of wit and parts▪
'Tis as good a ridiculous Cit as e'er was seen.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: He is a very farce, nothing but ridicule.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Believe me, Madam, this Gentleman is one of the best friends.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You do me too great an honour.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: As gallant a man as lives.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I have no small esteem for him.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have not yet done any thing, Madam, to merit this Grace, but if your Ladyship please to command me any service, your Grace shall find I have such an inclination▪ to serve your▪ Highness, that it should be impossible for any man, were you a Princess ten times o'er.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: What means Mr. Iorden?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Have a care what you say.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, I forgot, and I beg your Princely pardon.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I understand not Mr. Iordens discourse.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You will spoil all.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha: O Lord, Madam, if I have offended you, I cry your Highness mercy.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Again, fie, fie, Mr. Iorden.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I vow it was out before I was aware.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden is too great a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
I hope, Madam, you'l not be offended, it is a custom he has got to give the title of Princess and Queen to all Ladies
that are extraordinary sair and beautiful, because like Princesses and Queens they rule, command, and are adored.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Had I not been interrupted, you are so very beautiful, I should have run on till I had call'd you Emperour and great Turk.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: How, Mr. Iorden? Empress and Sultaness you mean.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pauh, a man in love minds not what,— I should have call'd you Cherubin and Arch-angel, ere I had done.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Are you then in love, Mr. Iorden?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: There I am caught again. Who I? no, Madam, not I.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What do you mean to deny it now?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I am not well.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Do you see what you have done?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam, I am in love, I am in love.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Indeed? ah me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: She swoons, run for some spirits.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Stay, she revives.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am in love, Madam, I assure you.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Help, help.

div.stage: Enter Lucia, a Gentlewoman, and a Page with a little Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What out-cry is this?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh Daughter, help, the Lady swoons.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: O my dear Prin—, my dear Mistress.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Dear Prin— O have I caught you tripping too.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Hy ho.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: how do you, Madam?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Pretty well, Mr. Doctor, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Madam, here is my Daughter come to wait on you.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Her company perfects my recovery.
How wondrous pretty she is, she's so like you, Mr. Iorden, I must needs salute her once more.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Observe that; like you, and kisses her again.

sp.speaker: Lue.
sp.p: Madam, you are all obliging, and I merit nothing of this favour.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Madam, here is the Cabinet you committed to my care.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden, in this trunck is all my present concern, will you pardon me, if I request the trouble of you to see it safe lockt up.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l take care of it my self, and put it into my Iron chest, where I keep my own little treasure.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: You shall see what it contains; look you, Sir, here is a small parcel of gold, some six thousand pounds, with some trifling Jewels, to the value of about two thousand pounds more, not worth your seeing.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Mr. Iorden will see 'em carefully dispos'd of.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: They shall be forth-coming when you please.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I have twelve thousand pound more to receive of the Banquers next week, for some friends of mine, alas I am not worth near so much.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: That is because I should not think her a person of great Quality, I understand her wheedle.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Mr. Doctor, I find my self very drowsie.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Your spirits, Madam, are faint, and weak; retire a while to your Chamber, one half hours repose will much refresh and enliven you.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Woman, where are you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Madam, my Daughter shall wait on you too.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: It were a disease to part with her, nothing I'l assure you can delight me more than her company.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to esteem it.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Page, wait on Mr. Iorden with my Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Mr. Doctor, I'l wait on you immediately.

div.stage: Betty Trickmore, Lucia and Woman exeunt.
Enter to Cureal Young Jorden and Jaques.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: 'Tis well you give me timely notice of the deceit. I wonder'd indeed at my Fathers sudden change.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Te reconcilement was good for te present, you give me your pardon.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: You did very well.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: All things succeed wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: The grand Masque is ready, the Play-house has furnish'd us rarely with habits; the Masquerade seems a little burlesque, but 'twill pass upon him, it hits his humour so right.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What with his love for Marina, and his ambition for our German Princess, his brain is so unsetled, he cannot frame a judgement so much as whether a thing be possible, or not; much less discern 'twixt probabilities, and improbabilities.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Sir, I have had remorse of conscience for contending with you for Marina, but to make a perfect amends, and to gain your pardon entirely, I have us'd all my endeavours to perswade her to love you: and, Sir, I have so prevailed that she has promised her Father, she will be your Wife, if you demand it of her to night.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, to night? I am busle.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I am sorry for it, for her father has given her leave to make a vow never to be your wife unless you consummate the marriage this very night.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Doctor, what do you advise me to?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: To think of the Princess.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But does she love me think you?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: She swoon'd when you said you did not love.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, and when I said I did, too.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: She was then possess'd with jealousie, that you lov'd some other Lady: you may, Mr. Iorden, let a Princess dye for you; but it will not be done like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, won't it be like a Gentleman? Well, Son, let 'em know if they are in such haste, they may do as they please.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Will you not go to her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have other fish to catch. You may tell Mrs. Marina, they that will not when they may, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: After this night you will have no hopes.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: There, or in another place. What, marriage is a matter of moment, and I will first consult with my pillow.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I am sorry you are so much disgusted.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It may be, anon I may send my man to 'em, and it may be not.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I have business that way, if you please I'l serve you in that occasion, and tell 'em your mind.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pray do.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: There be Maitre Iorden.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, I have not the honour to be known to you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Nor I the like to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I remember I have seen you at my Fathers, when we were Children, your Father used to bring you sometimes to our house; you was the prettiest sweet babe, the women did love to get you upon their knees, and kiss you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Kiss me!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your father and mine were great Cronies.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I am sorry to hear he is dead, he was a very honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I say he was a very honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What, my Father?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, as liv'd.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And you knew him very well?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And you knew him to be a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Then I know not how the World goes.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: All the World knew him to be but a Shop-keeper.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He a Shop-keeper?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, a Mercer, was he not?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
He a Mercer? what because he was very obliging, and officious, and because he had great skill in silks, went
up and down and bought 'em, and had 'em sent home to his house, and gave 'em to his friends and acquaintance for their money; therefore he was a Shop-keeper, was he?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I always thought him a Shop-keeper: but I am glad to understand from you that my Father was a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He was, and I'l maintain it.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you for it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Since I saw him (good Gentleman) which is now about twenty years, I have travelled almost o'er all the World.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O'er all the World?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, o'er all the World.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: 'Tis a great way thither.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It is but four days since I have been in Town after my long travels, and to morrow or next day I am to depart again.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your own Country after so long an absence, should methinks be too dear to you to part again so soon.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A mans Country is where he can make his fortune, I am lately got into a great imploy.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What, I pray?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I am the now great Turks English Interpreter, and have been so this fortnight.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Are you come so far as from Turkey in a fortnight?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, the great Turk is here.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What, in England?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, he is here.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Here? what in London?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, and in this house.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The great Turk in my house?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, and a great train with him.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: In my house? in this house?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: In this very house; he is come to visit a Lady that is newly come hither, and to take his leave of her.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How came he to know her, and that she was here?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
He grew acquainted with her in Germany; and at
her old lodgings they informed us of her remove, which I was glad to hear; for by this means I have an opportunity to pay my respects to you, Sir, whom I honour for your fathers sake.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, how came the great Turk to be in Christendom?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Do not you remember you had the news some while since that the great Turks brother was taken by a Squadron of the French-fleet, as he was sayling to Mecha, to pay his devotions at Mahomet's Shrine?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I heard that indeed.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The King of France generously restor'd him to liberty, and he since that time has travell'd over most part of Christendom, and is now come to England; but since his arrival at London, which is now but two days, news is come that his Brother who was the Sultan, is dead, and he is to succeed him in his Empire, which occasions his sudden departure, for to morrow, or next day, he is to set sail for Turkey, attended with a Squadron of the Kings Frigats, which his Majesty sends to be his Convoy.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.p: Ehhim, acha halif ulabalechi.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Alman bochin. Mr. Iorden, I am commanded to go about some affairs, but I'l wait on you again before my great Lord the Sultan turns his posteriors to the front of your Palace.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your servant, Mr. Interpreter. Mr. Iack, where is this great Turk?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Above vid te Lade.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Who showed him up?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Her Shentilewoman.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha! he smells her out to be a Princess, he is my Rival: go fetch me my long Sword and Pumps.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ha, vat do you mean?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ne'er a great Turk in Christendom shall rob me of my Princess.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ho Princess! my Maitre be troubled in te esprete.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He is my Rival, and I'l fight him.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You fight te great Turk?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l challenge him, and kill him by the trick I learnt to day.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Oh he have te grand train vit te Cemiter dat vil sa, sa, sa, cut off te head, and te arm at one blow.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well then, I will play the Polititian: the Dialogue we omitted at dinner, in hopes this would have prov'd mine or my Daughters wedding-night, shall be performed by way of Cerenade, and I will plant my self below o'er against the Balcony; and if I espie his Turkship making any courtship to her, I will put my self into a posture of terrour, and look so grum upon the matter, that he shall think me a Devil or a Rival.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Does Sir Simon then believe he has killed me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I put him into a fear that he has done you some mischief so soon as I disingag'd him from you at the door; for I got his sword out of his hand, and cut my finger with it, and bloodied the point, which much surpriz'd him; then I hurryed him away in great haste to that house, where I caused some persons to come and report the news of your death, which has put him into such fear, that he is resolv'd to leave the Town in disguise to avoid being apprehended.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: By that means we shall get quit of him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The posture our affairs are in at present, do not much seem to require his absence, therefore I have contriv'd a defeat, and will keep him yet in play. I have set another Spring, which if it catch the Woodcock, 'twill hold him fast. Look here comes forth our Knight in Petty-coats: mussle your self up in your Cloak, and be gon.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: A stately dame on my word.

div.stage: Enter Sir Simon Softhead, in the habit of a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I am in a bodily fear for you, but I think you cannot be known in this disguise, I would not for the World see you hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nor I for the world you should see so sad a sight: but I don't flee so much for the fear of death, as that it would be a dishonourable thing to be hang'd; it would be a blur to our Family, and much below the dignity of Knighthood; were I of a mean discent, or a poor Devil, it were another matter.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Right, hanging then would not be so much, it were more suitable to ones condition. Come, Sir, I'l lead you off, think to demean your self like a woman of Quality, and carry your self with some state.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Shaw waugh: let me alone for that, I know how to carry my self like a Lady of honour. I warrant you; but have I not a little too much beard?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Some women have as much: but put your Mask on, that will hide it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I have ne'er a Mask.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I laid a Vizard Mask with the rest of your things, I'l step in and fetch it: Do you practise a good carriage in the mean time.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: A pox on this Sir Simon Softhead, that he should get away already.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: O that we could find him, that we might get the twenty pounds, Mr. Iorden offers them that can bring him before a Justice.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ha, these are hounds upon the scent for me.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: I am as weary as a dog with running about, but hang't he's gone, we got crowns a piece to encourage us to begin the search, e'en let us go and be merry now.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I would ye were gone, that I might be a little merry too.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: I'faith Comrade, we'l have a Wench if we can get one, I'l try if I can pick up that Gentlewoman, she looks like a good brazon'd fac'd Quean.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: How shall I behave my self now? these fellows understand no breeding.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: What, Mistress, are you here all alone?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, now you are here I am not alone.

div.stage: Sir Simon counterfeiting a womans voice.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Mistress, if you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Keep your hands off, they don't please.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Here is excellent liquor hard by, pray let us wait on you to take a pot.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I am not such a one as you take me for.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Faith she's a good bonny Lass: Pray give me your hand, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: O'er your ears, and you will ye saucy Rascals, I am a person of Quality.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Oh we know how to be civil.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Oh Rogue, what a breast is there, I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ye are the rudest insolent fellows I e'er saw in my life.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Aye he's a rude Rogue, go with me Mistress.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Go with you Comrade?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Let go my hand.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Aye, let go her hand; come, Madam, you and I.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Let me go both of you: is this usage to be offer'd to a person of Quality? let go my hands, or I'll spit in your faces.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Come, Madam, come this way.

div.stage: They tug him about from one to another.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: No this way; I know where there is the best drink

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: You lye, I know best: this way, Madam.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: No, come this way.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You uncivil, unmannerly fellows, how ye haul and pull me, I'l kick your arses for you soundly.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam. O, O.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, good Madam.

div.stage: Enter Cureal in the habit of a Constable.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ha! what is here to do? I charge you in the Kings name to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
You unmannerly Rogues pick me up? I'l
make ye know I am a man— a woman of Quality.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I'l have 'em before a Justice, if you please, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I pray do Mr. Constable, they have pull'd me almost limb from limb, the Rogues would have ravish'd me.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: O good, Mr. Constable, we were but in quest of the Knight that kill'd the Gentleman, we thought this might be he in disguise, and went to search.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: O what a mischievous lye has the Rogue told for an excuse.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Go, be gone about your business.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I thank you, Mr. Constable, I know not how to make you an amends for my deliverance.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: 'Twill be an amends sufficient, if you prove to be the person they took you for, 'twill be twenty pound in my way.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, I find by the constitution of my body here will be foul work.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: By all circumstances you must be Sir Simon, you have a masculine spirit, I saw you boxing, and kicking a little too heroically for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh I can hold no longer.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And a word slipt from you unawares e'en now, I heard you say, as I am a man of Quality: Let me observe you well; faugh, I smell you out; oh there are the stumps of a beard and all.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I am undone: Good Mr. Constable, I am not he you look for.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Well, well, come before Mr. Iorden, we shall soon know who you are.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr. Constable.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Heavens! Sir Simon, what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O, lo you there, you are Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh discovered: undone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yes, yes, come; come a-long.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
Nay Mr. Constable, you and I have been old friends,
pray, for my sake let him go, and say you saw him not.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ne'er talk on't.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You were won't to esteem my friendship; come, pray let us adjust the business; Sir Simon, pull out your gold.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh cursed London!

sp.speaker: Cur.
