sp.p: Pray Mr. Trickmore, think not of any such thing, I dare not do it, I protest.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hold, hold your hand, there's gold, there are twenty Guinneys, Mr. Constable.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: The reward is so much to take him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And there it is, not to take; him a thing sooner done by half.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, but the breach of my duty, it is my office.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, there are twenty more.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Not for a thousand, I protest.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Not for a thousand? then it is a thousand pound to a penny, but I shall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir Simon, how much was in the purse?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A hundred Guinneys.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Shall I give him all if he'l take 'em?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: All, all: I would not be hang'd for a hundred thousand.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Here, Mr. Constable, take all in the purse: a hundred I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I would not take it, but that I have a device in my head may secure me: look you, Sir, I have hold of Sir Simon: do you now pull him away by force: so, now if his escape be found out, you will be call'd in question for it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, I'l venture more than that to serve Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Now he can do it with security, he might afford to give me half my money back again.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Have a care of marring the matter. But pray tell me Mr. Constable is young Mr. Iorden dead?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
I have some reason to think he is not at all hurt, but
that this is a design of theirs to bring Sir Simon into trouble▪ and that the son conceals himself in his Fathers house to this purpose: But for fear it should be otherwise, get you gone so soon as you can, to prevent danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye, let's be on the safer side. As my shirt sticks to me like a Cerecloath.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Away, I hear a noise, more are coming this way, I'l go and delay 'em till you get clear.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Well, excepting your self, this is the only man of honesty I have met with here in Town, but I perceive it is scarce with him, he sells it so dear.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Vertue, Sir Simon must be encouraged; come, Sir, while you go in and dress you, I'l pretend business to Mr. Iorden's house, and find out whether his son hath receiv'd any hurt or not; and bring you word.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Jorden, Musick, two Shepherds, and a Shepherdess.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Musick, plant your selves under that Window, away with it smartly and briskly: so, this has allarm'd 'em to the Balcony. Now you to your Dialogue, and I to my posture.

div.stage: Cleverwit in Turks habit with Betty Trickmore and Lucia appear in the Balcony, Jorden stands making grimaces all the while the Song is sung.
Two Shepherds, and a Shepherdess betwixt 'em, sing.

lg.l: A heart in loves Empire, tho' jocund, and blyth
From cares, and from fears can never he free:
'Tis said that with pleasure we languish and sigh;
But for all can be urg'd, there's nothing can be
So pleasant, so pleasant as our libertie.
None are more happy, nor none are more blest
Than whom Love doth inspire, with a gentle, soft fire;
When both of them sigh, and neither can rest,
How pleasant their pantings, how sweet their desire!
Love is a blessing, tho' counted a Pain;
For take away Love, no pleasures remain.
To submit to Loves Law, ah sweet it would be,
If in Love we 〈◊〉 any fidelity see:
But O Rigour extream! O fate too unkind!
A Shepherdess faithful, no man can find:
And this faithless Sex so unworthy doth prove,
They ought not to live, or ought not to love.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Ah passion most sweet!

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Ah blest libertie!

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Sex full of deceit!

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: How dear unto me!

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: How my heart you do ease!

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: And how mine you displease!

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Ah quit thou for love this hatred so great▪

lg.l: A Shepherdess you,
May find that is true.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: But alas! where can she be met?

lg.l: Our credits to save, my heart▪
I do offer—

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: — O subtle Art!

lg.l: But Shepherdess may I believe,
That it wonnot it wonnot deceive?
By experience let us try,
Who can love best you or I.
To them that constancy want,
May the Gods ne▪ er their wishes grant.
Let's permit the soft fire,
To enflame our desire.
Ah! how pleasant, how pleasant is love,
When two hearts faithful do prove!

div.stage: Young Jorden and Marina in the Balcony are against 'em▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He treats his new Mistress with a great deal of gallantry.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord▪
sp.p: Now dearest Marina, let us ascend to your Father, he is by this time from his Window convine'd of the slight is put on you; hang about his neck, use all your little arts and pretty blandishments to gain his consent: you have powerful charms in your perswasions, such as will mollifie the most rigid natures.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He does not at all dislike your person.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: And I will induce him to consider the hopes I have of an estate, notwithstanding my fathers extravagant humour, I'l shew him what I have in present, and what more I hope from the event of this night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am called.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Come it is your Fathers voice.

div.stage: Jorden stands all this while in a posture, with his eyes fix'd on the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Iorden, Mr. Iorden, I have most advantageous news for you: My Lord and Master the Grand Seignior is mightily in love with your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, with my Daughter!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: With my Daughter, said you?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He has a mind to be your Son in-Law.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The great Turk be my Son-in-Law?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he call'd me to him just now, and speaking in his own Language, said, Acciam croc soler ouch alla Moustaphi gidelum amanahem vorahini oussere carbulath, (That is to say) This is that fair person I yesterday saw pass along the street: This is she I languish'd for, and knew not where to find.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The Great Turk say this of my Lucie!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I told him she was wondrous beautiful: Then, said he, Marababa sahem, Ah how much in love am I!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Marababa sahem, mean, ah how much in love am I!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p:
I am beholden to you for telling me, for I could ne'er
have thought that Marababa sahem, should signifie, Ah how much in love am I! Ah this Turkish is a most admirable Language.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Much better than one could imagine; do you know what means cacaracamouchen?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Cacaracamouchen? no.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: That is to say, my pretty Pigsnie.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Cacaracamouchen, signifie my pretty Pigsnie?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It is a most excellent Language: cacaracamouchen, my pretty Pigsnie: ah that a Turk should say so!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: In fine, to tell you my whole embassey, he is coming down to demand your Daughter in marriage, and to make you worthy to be his Father-in-Law, he will make you a Mamamouchi, which is the greatest honour and dignity among the Turks.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A Mamamouchi?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, a Mamamouchi; that is to say, a Paladin, and a Paladin is a sort of the most ancient. In fine, a Paladin is a Paladin, and a Paladin and a Mamamouchi are all one and the same thing: nothing is more noble in the world, and you may walk cheek by Jowl with the greatest Seigniors upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The Grand Seignior honours me very much, and I beseech you conduct me to him, to kiss his hand and give him thanks.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, he is coming down to you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He come down to me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, and will instal you in the dignity; it is his custom where e'er he goes to visit, to present the Master of the house with a Turkish habit, and you will instantly have one brought to you to put on.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: That will be noble.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He will consummate the marriage to night.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: That will be quick dispatch.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: His love cannot brook delay, within a day he departs hence, he will take you and your Daughter a▪ long with him to Turkey, if you'l go.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But all that I fear, is my Daughter should be averse to the marriage; she is a little untoward sometimes in cases of this nature.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: O, but to be the Grand Seigniors wife, she to be the Sultaness, and you a Mamamouchi! O she cannot refuse this. See, Sir, there comes the greatest man that walks upon the earth.

div.stage: Enter Cleverwit in Turkish habit, his train carried up by three Blacks, Turkish attendants, and three Turks with Vest, Turbant, Cemiter and Shoes.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Ambousahim, oqui boraf, Iordina, sala ma lecqui.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: That is to say, Mr. Iorden, may your heart be all the year round like a Rose Tree, full of buds. This is the manner of speaking obligingly in that Country.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am his highness the great Turks most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Carigar, cambito oustin moraf.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Oustin yoc catamalequi basum, basè alla moran.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He wishes Heaven may give you the strength of Lyons, and the prudence of Serpents.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: His High and mighty Highness the great Turk does me too great an honour, and I wish him all the happiness in the World.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ossa binamen sadoc babally oracaf ouram.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Bell men.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He says, these shall wait on you to cloath you in that habit, in order to the ceremony of making you a Mamamouchi, and for the celebrating the Rites of your Daughters Marriage.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: All that in two words?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: O, Sir, the Turkish Language is very significant, much may be said in few words. But to be a Mamamouchi, you must be a Mahometan.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I do not much scruple to change my religion, for any will serve my turn; but methinks it is not a Gentleman-like quality to change, tho' a man be sure of a better.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But to be a Mamamouchi you must be a Mahometan.

lg.l: Then long live Mahomet.
Who stops when honour calls is but a Lourdane,
Honour need but to beckon Master Iorden.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene draws open, and discovers Cleverwit sitting in state, Lucia on his right hand, and Betty Trickmore on his left, Attendants of Turks on each side the Throne. The Mufti with a Turbant stuck full of Lights, sitting at his feet.
Enter To solemn Musick on each side of the Stage, many Turks bowing their bodies to Cleverwit. After them

Enter Two Dervises leading in Mr. Jorden dress'd in a Turkish Vest: But without Turbant, Sash or Cemiter; follow'd by Trickmore, dancing Turks and others bearing in the Turbant, Sash and Cemiter. The Mufti rises and takes Mr. Jorden to the Bottom of the Stage and Sings.

lg.l: Seti sabir
Ti respondir
Se non Sabir
Tazir, Tazir
Mi star Mufti
Tiqui star ti
Non Intendir
Tazir, Tazir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He bids you hold your peace.

div.stage: The Mufti runs Jorden backward, sits down by him on the foot of the Throne; the Turks dance; then the Mufti rises, and the Dervises hurry Jorden down to the bottom of the Stage again.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now the Mufti will demand what Religion you are of.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Anabaptista, Anabaptista.

sp.speaker: Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Brunista, Brunista.

sp.speaker: Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Calvanista, Calvanista.

sp.speaker: Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Papista, Papista.

sp.speaker: Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Mohometana, Mahometana.

sp.speaker: Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: Hivalla, Hivalla, Hivalla.
Chou, Chou, Chou.

div.stage: At this the dancing Turks which stood round him, shrink up their shoulders, and jump backward till they come to each side of the Stage, and stand in Antick postures; the Mufti makes signs of invocating Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Mahametta, Mahametta, Mahametta.

sp.speaker: 2 Derv.
sp.p: Mahametta, &c.

lg.l: Mahametta per Giourdina
Mi pregar, sera é Mattina
Voler far un Paladina
Dé Giourdina, de Giourdina
Dar Turbanta é dar scarcinae
Con Galera é Brigantina
Per defender Palastina
Mahometta, &c.

div.stage: The Dervises set the Turbant on Mr. Jordens head, and gird him with the Sash.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Star Bon Turca Giourdina.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He tells you, you are now made a Turk.

sp.speaker: Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: Hivalla, Hivalla, Hivalla.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hivalla, Hivalla, &c.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Chou, chou, chou.
sp.stage: The Mufti stamps to quiet them. Jorden falls back in imitation of the Turks before.
sp.p: Hula baba la chou, ba la haba la da.

sp.speaker: 2 Derv. and Turk
sp.p: ala baba, &c.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hula ba, &c.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Chou, chou, chou.

div.stage: The Dervises bring Jorden forward again.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now you must answer for your self.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Ti non star Furba.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He asks you if you are a Knave?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Ti non star Furfanta.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He asks if you are a Paltroon.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Mufti.
sp.p: Donar Turbanta, Donar Turbanta.

sp.speaker: Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: Donar Turbanta, &c.

lg.l: Ti star Nobile é non star fabbola
Pigilar Schiabbola.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He tells you, you are ennobled, and bids you take the Cemiter.

sp.speaker: 2 Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: Tistar Nobile, &c.

lg.l: Dara Dara
Bastonnara Bastonnara.

sp.speaker: 2 Derv. and Turks.
sp.p: Dara Dara.

div.stage: Here the Dervises run him back to's seat again, and the dancing Turks brandish their Cemiters about him. The Mufti sits down, the Dervises stand on each hand of him. The Turks dance, and at the end of the Dance make a lane; holding their Cemiters in threatning postures: the Mufti and Dervises run Jorden into the middle of them.

lg.l: Non tener Honta.
Questa star ultima affront.

sp.speaker: 2 Derv. and the Turks.
sp.p: Non tener, &c.

div.stage: Here the Mufti and Turks turn round a good while as fast as they can, and the Dervises makes Jorden turn round as fast: They stop on a sudden, and stand all bowing to Mr. Jorden: Then solemn Musick plays, and Cleverwit discends to Jorden, and lays both his hands on his head.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Mamamouchi, Paladin, Paladin.

div.stage: Exit leading off Betty Trickmore and Lucia. The Stage clears in order: solemn Musick plays all the while.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The Sultan saluted you as he went off by the Title of Mamamouchi and Paladin.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O there is a great grace in the sound of Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The next thing you are to do, may it so please the illustrious Mamamouchi, is to give your Daughter in Marriage to the Sultan, and to set your hand and seal to those writings are drawing within to convey your Land away.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: But why must not a Mamamouchi have Land?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A Mamamouchi is the greatest honour a subject can be rais'd to, and to have Lands is not consistent with so great a Dignity, because it implyes a kind of slavery and servitude.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Humh.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Another reason is, they are men in great Power; and if they might be Possessors of Land, they might in time purchase whole Countries, and raise Armies of their Tenants, and become Rebels.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Humh.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And for this cause no subject of the mighty Sultans is permitted to have any inheritance of Land. You my great Master and Illustrious Mamamouchi, will have yearly coming in no less than fourscore or a hundred thousand pound a year.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, my Daughter will be provided for by her Marriage, I am going a Mamamouchi into Turkey: My Son shall have my Land, and stay in England to continue the name, that after ages may know, from whence came Ionathan Iorden the great Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
I'l leave you to the congratulation of your friends,
that will be flocking to you to salute you by your new title.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Iack, approach:
It is now below me to give you the title of Master, I must now call thee Iack; for thou seest I am created a Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: A Mam— hi, hi, hi?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Vat be you, Sir, a Mama— hi, hi, hi?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I am a Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: A Mamamou— hi, hi, hi?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How dares thee knave laugh before a Mamamouchi?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: A Mamamouchi— hi, hi, hi?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What does the slave mean?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Maitre Iorden be a Mamamouchi— hi, hi, hi?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Grand insolence!

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O me demand pardon of te great Mamamouchi— hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I will not indure this.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Me be trouble very mush, but me can no hold to see, hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Slave, to see what?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: To see, hi, hi hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hold, or Il run my fist down your throat.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Me demand pardon on me two knee, hi, hi, hi, you are so pleasant, hi, hi, hi, tat me ne'er see te like, hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Thou French Rascal!

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You be so comical, tat— hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Insufferable, intolerable, insupportable.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Excuse me but a little, hi, hi, hi,

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Take warning, or by Mahomet, and the great Turk, thy chastisement shall be most bloudy.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O, me have done, hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hear then.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: You Iack shall go with me into Turkey, and be my French Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ouy Monsieur, hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Are you snearing again?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Hi, hi, hi, here, Sir, beat a me, box me, buffet me,
kick me, give me to bastonado; but no, hi, hi, hi, hinder me laugh, hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Then by the Turbant of a Mamamouchi my revenge shall cut the off.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Hi, hi, hi. O, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What out-cry is this?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O my Master is huzzaing the Munfu.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, what do you mean to kill him?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I have sworn by Mahomet, and cannot in honour come off without his head.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O pray make te agreement, me only laugh'd out my laugh, hi, hi, hi.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Laugh at a Mamomouchi?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Did not duty restrain me, I could not forbear; this strange garb and alteration will raise laughter where e'er you go.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, I am going where a Mamamouchi is adored.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir, by Mamamouchi?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I mean Paladin a certain kind, of Paladin, and Mamamouchi are all one.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: A certain kind of wild beast, is it not?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I tell you, I am a Mamamouchi, it is a certain kind of honour amongst the Turks: In fine, had you come a little sooner, you might have seen the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What Ceremony?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Mahometa par Iordina.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Iordina, that is to say Iorden.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Volar far un Paladina de Iordina.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Dar turbanta con gulera.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What signifies this?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Per defender Palestina.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: What mean you by all this?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Dara, dara bastonnara.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Strange kind of gibberish this!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Non tener honta questa star l'ultima affronta.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, let me but know what all this signifies.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hou la baba la chou, ba la ba ba la da.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir, you are going distracted.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Peace, insolent, learn to behave your self with more respect to a Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I come not to offend you, but to acquaint you, that fair Marina's Father is so incens'd against her for provoking you to quit your intentions, that he has turn'd her out of doors, and vowed in his anger never to see her face, till she has reconcil'd you to her, and is become your Wife.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: My Wife! the case is altered now, I am a Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Sir, I was in part the occasion of her misfortune, therefore give me leave to intreat you to be kind to her.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, she has not state nor grandeur enough in her person to be a Mamamoucha, Paladina. Here comes my Princess, ha with what a swoop and haughty mein she marches forward! Go you in and peruse the writings are drawing, and you will see what you get by my being a Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I come to pay the first tribute of homage to your new dignity, and to wish you much joy of the Election of your Daughter to the Grandeur of Sultanness.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.stage: Making reverences after the Turkish mode
sp.p: Madam, I wish you the strength of Serpents, and the prudence of Lyons.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I am proud of the honour I have to be the first that comes to salute you by the title of Great and Illustrious.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Madam, I wish that you may be all the year round like a Rose-tree full of buds, that I may have the gathering them, that with the breath of Mamamouchi they may be full blown, that they may ever flourish in the Sun-shine of Paladines prosperity, and that—

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: That would be an honour, Sir, too great.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Say, will they kindly admit the influence of my love?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p:
Ah, can the heart of a Mamamouchi descend
from the high mountain top of honour to perch upon a Rose-tree that grows in the valley?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Marababa sahem, that is by way of being my own interpreter: Ah how in love am I!

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: With thee Cacaracamouchen my pretty pigsnie.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: But do you love me?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Thee, and only thee, by Mahomet.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: After this assurance, I no longer will conceal the secret of my Quality; then Prince Mamamouchi, I am not below your love: here, Sir, take my hand, and know that by birth I am—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Little thinks she I know already— what.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Prevented.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: In what an unluky minute comes she here?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Iorden, is it thus you treat a harmless maid! can you be so cruel after all your vows of love and proffer'd kindness to forsake me? Ah, did the message of my love merit no better a return than scorn?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: How! what do I hear!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Puh, Madam, mind not her idle story.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Is it possible you should be faithless and unconstant?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I unconstant? no, no, it is not in my nature.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Do you then love her still? ah me!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I love her? that's a good one: look you, Madam, does she seem fit to be a Mamamoucha or a Paladina; no, no, 'tis you I love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Twas me you did love.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy prating.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You have forsaken and undone me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I think the wench is mad; look you, to put you out of your pain, see here I bestow my hand and heart.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Wou'd you deceive me too?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I vow—

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Hold dissembler, let me vow first.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hear me.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: I vow not to hear, nor see you this—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hold, ah hold, hold.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: This half-hour— nor love you if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ah hapless Maid, what has fate in reserve for thee but death, that art abandon'd by a Father, and by a Lover forsaken? Unkind and cruel man farewel, you soon shall hear that I am dead, laid in the cold grave, cover'd o'er with earth, and then forgotten as now forsaken.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What means my friend by this sad posture?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I vow to you,
sp.stage: Jorden blubbers all the while he speaks.
sp.p: Mr. Doctor, I cannot help it; I cannot but grieve; I was always good natur'd; I ought to pitty her; for the truth on't is I, I, I, have wrong'd her poor thing!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Truly my heart melts too, and I have brine in my eyes, I cannot but mourn to see a Mamamouchi weep. But the very sound of that word comforts and rejoyces me.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And so it does me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I heard the news within, and came in haste to wish long life, continual health, and all hearts ease to my friend the Illustrious Paladin. Come, Sir, think no more of her, it was her own fault.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And so it was; but, Mr. Doctor, she came in the most unlucky minute.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Just as my Princess was about to give me her hand in earnest of her heart, she bolts in, and interrupts us with her whining.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Strange accident!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Had she staid but one minute longer, we had struck up the bargain.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And she was just upon discovery to me who she was.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: All will out, Love can keep no secrets.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: She grew jealous presently, and banish'd me her presence.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But for half an hour, if she can be without your company so long.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: She had no sooner heard love named, but she flew off.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You'l have her come about again, like a bird that is scared, which takes a flight round, and lights just in the same place.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I long till the half hour is out, that I may be at her again.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: In the mean time introduce me to the Sultan as a friend of yours, that I may give him my respects as your Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Come I'l recommend you to him as my special good friend.

div.stage: Enter Sir Simon in a Cloak in his Shirt, and drawers underneath, and Trickmore.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your cloaths stole? which way?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I left 'em on the chair under the window: when I went in I found the window open.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Being a ground room it was an easie matter. Well, but I bring you good news after all; Mr. Iorden is no more hurt than you or I.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay then I care not.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I saw him go in and out at his Fathers house two or three times.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Did you?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, now I'l carry you to your lodging, I have a friend lives at the end of this street, will make you very welcome for my sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; I am so infinitely beholden to you.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Here they are.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'l keep on my Mask, that Sir Simon may not know me.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Ah Gentlemen, Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Ah, if ye are noble Gentlemen, give protection to a distressed Virgin.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir Simon, it is the height of gallantry, and the glory of Knighthood to succour beauty in distress. Madam, be your cause what it will, here are those will stand your champions.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: This adventure makes me think I am a Knight errant.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Declare fair Damsel what your disasters are, that by the knowledge of them, we may judge how capable we are to serve you.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: My Father dying while I was an infant, deliver'd me to the care of his-brother, and in his last Will commanded me to respect my uncle, as I would have done him, had he liv'd; and there left me ten thousand pound in money, and six hundred pounds a year in Land. But the moyty to be forfeited, if I marry'd without this Uncles consent; but he covetous wretch, is now grown so inhumanely cruel, that he would sell me to one I ne'er can love, for half my portion, and force me to be his wife: This five thousand pound here in gold

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ha, gold, see, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Gold indeed!

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Was the price my Uncle sold me for, and this is the night I should have been forced to marry against my will: but whilst my Uncle and intended husband were consulting about my Joynture, my Damsel and I found an opportunity, encourag'd by this Gold and these Jewels to make an escape.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A pretty adventure.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Aye, Sir Simon, 'twere pretty indeed, if the story would run on in adventures, till at last it ended as Romances do with a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: And I the man.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh, 'twould be a solecism in a Romance to make the Lady distressed marry any other than the Knight had rescu'd her.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Five thousand pounds in hand, and all these Jewels.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Besides you'l recover the rest. Lady, this Knight vows he will protect you not only this night, but as long as the fates permit him to draw vital breath.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: The deceased daughter of old Goodhope thanks you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Goodhope! are you indeed his Daughter?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I knew him well, and was one of the witnesses to the Will you speak of. Could you but get this Girl, Sir Simon, you would not lose your labour of coming to Town. But, Madam, who was the man your Uncle would compel you to marry?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: One Mr. Iorden:

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Iorden! 'twould be a rare revenge if you could get Iordens Mistress from him.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: But rather than be his wife, I have vowed to marry the first Gentleman that asks me the question.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: If I can serve you, sweet Virgin, think of no other.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Madam, I hear a noise. It may be somebody coming in quest of you.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: O courteous Knight conduct me to some place where I may find a refuge.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: My Arms shall be your sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir Simon, we'l stay now at this house, here lodges a young Oxford Parson of my acquaintance, and if the Lady please to let him pronounce the spell of Matrimony, she will no longer be in danger of them that pursue her.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Yonder is somebody coming.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Away, Sir, with sword in hand like a valiant Hero, and stout Champion, lead off the Virgin in defiance of danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Which thus I do.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I as your Squire, will follow with the Damsel, and guard the Gold.

div.stage: Sir Simon, Betty Trickmore, Trickmore, Lucia, exeunt.
Enter Mr. Jorden, Cureal, Young Jorden.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: There: now you are Master of my whole estate, all is your own.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: This is a sad bounty, Sir, which gives me your Estate, and deprives me of your self: but must I never see you more?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: May I not once in ten years make a voyage to see you, Sir, at Constantinople?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I thought what you'd be at, but to confine you in England, I have setled my Estate upon you conditionally, and you forfeit it to Mr. Doctor here, if ever you travel out of the three Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I should have been glad to have seen you in your grandeur in Turkey, and to have had the honour of being owned by a Mamamouchi for his Son, but since you will not have it so—

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Look you friend, now you shall see my Sultan Son-in-Law, I know the first word will be to ask for my Daughter, therefore, Son, go see if she is dress'd, and bid her come away.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I am, may it please you mighty Sultan, an intimate friend of your noble Father-in-Law here, the new created Mamamouchi: I come to pay you my most profound respects and services, and to do reverence to the hem of your Vest.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Where is this Interpreter now to tell him who you are, and what it is you say? Ah you shall hear how obligingly he will answer you, where a-duce is this man gone?
Strouf, strif, strof, straf; this is a Doc-tore, a Doc-tore, a grand man with the King, a Mamamouchi English: Euh, I cannot make him understand me better.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Cacaracamouchen.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye, your Cacaracamouchen is dressing, dressing, I knew he would be asking for my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Marababasahem.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye, and she is Marababasahem.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He tells me, he is deeply in love.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Teives, teives, teives, begar.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hark, they cry Thieves.

sp.speaker: Iord and Iaq.
sp.p: Euh.

div.stage: Jorden is going out in haste, Jaques enters, runs against him, and almost beats him backward.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Villain, hadst thou a mind to be the death of a Mamamouchi?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O me beg te pardon. But me come to tell you of Teives, Rogues, you be rob, rob of your gold, rob of your money.

sp.speaker: Iord. and Cur.
sp.p: Rob'd?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Me had te occasion to go into your Shambré, and me find your shest, your iron shest open, noting witin, all gone, gone.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No Cabinet? no gold.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: No, no Cabinet, no Gold, no Money, noting at all, all gone, all gone.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Find out the Thief, or you are he.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Teif, teif, jernè Frenchman and Teif, begar find out te Teif your self, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ah good Iack, good Mr. Iack, find out the Thief has stole the Cabinet, the Jewels, my Princess Jewels.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O ho den Maitre Iacques be no Teif.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, run, run, cry stop Thief, stop Thief.

div.stage: Runs up and down the Stage.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Cassa molou.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh rob'd, rob'd, rob'd of my Princess Jewels: Thieves, Thieves, Thieves.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye, undone, undone, the Cabinet, the Jewels.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: My Sister, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No, no, she has 'em not.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Is stole, is gone.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye, aye, they are stole, and gone, quite gone.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, my Sister is stole, my Sister is gone.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Your Sister gone too!

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, gone away, run away, stole away.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: O unfortunate Mamamouchi! lose my gold, lose my daughter; and now the Jewels are lost, I shall lose my Princess too. Oh undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Alas, alas!

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: She left this note on her Table to let you know she could not like the great Turk so well as another, you once approv'd of for her husband, and to avoid the marriage, is fled away into the arms of one will this night make her his Wife.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Oh, undone, undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Have patience, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Now shall not I be carryed into Turkey, but remain a sneaking Mamamouchi here in England.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What is your daughter gone?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, the baggage just as she was to have been the she great Turk, is run away.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: She is but at the next house, I saw her led in by a a man muffl'd in a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I'l follow, and prevent the dishonour of our Family.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Bring the baggage home.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A fortunate discovery.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pray tell his greatness, that this Gentleman is my special friend, and a person of much worth, and one that is ambitious of his smiles. Now you shall hear how he'l answer you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Alabala crociam, aceiboram alabamen.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Cutalequi tubal ourin soter amalouchen.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Loe you there.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He says, may the rain of prosperity always besprinkle the Garden of your Family.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: There's for you.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Fine, indeed.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Nay, I must deliver you into the hands of my Father: There, Sir, and now I'l send the Thief after her to you. Come Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ah graceless Girl!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Why, Madam, do you so ill requite a Father that is so provident for your good, and seeks to dispose of you with so much advantage: see what a glorious husband here stands ready for you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I pursued but mine own inclinations, he once approv'd of Sir Simon for his Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha! was he the man? he's a pockey beggerly Knight. Come give me your hand, I will dispose of you to more advantage, the grand Seignior does me the honour to demand you in marriage. Come, come near: immortal glory crown your nuptials.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Go too, give him your hand:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Marry a Turk?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, the great Turk.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I'l see it done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Sir, you have no power to force me to take any man but Sir Simon for my Husband.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Do't, or the breath of a Mamamouchi shall blast thee; do't, or may never the Rain of prosperity besprinkle thy Grass-plat.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Be obedient to your Father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In any thing but this.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: In this, or I'l send you beyond Sea to a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Use no violence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Rather let me dye than prove false to Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Take her hence, and let her be lock'd up all night in the Cellar, I'l pack her beyond Sea tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, I'l do any thing rather than go to a Nunnery, that were to be buryed alive.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: So then, down on your marrow-bones, ask him forgiveness for running away. Sir, I beseech you to tell him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Not that she fled away from his love: I'l tell him▪ she prostrates her self before him to know if he thinks her worthy to be his Sultana.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Pray do.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Bolac allim oustin malaf afti.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Boloma tafti.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: She shall be the Glove to his right hand.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ah, ha.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Elcan allhoim.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The Rose-bud in his Nose-gay.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Malta haraban.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The plum in his broth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pretty.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Croustan meli.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The crust to his bread: (which the Turks love wonderfully.)

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Tart of anachi.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A Jewel to wear at his heart.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Brave!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I, is it not?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Straca tafti.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The Joy of his soul.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Hulalli, hulalli.

sp.speaker: 2 Derv.
sp.p: Hulalli, hulalli, hulalli.

div.stage: Cleverwit throws his handkercheif in Lucia's bosome.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
His bed-fellow, his bed-fellow, his bed-fellow.
Madam; you must veil your face with that handkerchief, and suffer your self to be led by these Dervises to the Mufti who are prepar'd for the Ceremonies of the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Is it not a pretty Language?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Full of very obliging Phrases.

div.stage: The two Dervises lead out Lucia veiled with the handkercheif.
Enter, Sir Simon guarded, Jacques, Boy with the Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Allonz Teif, come along and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What a Devil do ye haul me, as if I had stole the mony.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Stole it? pray how came your worship by it else?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I came honourably by it▪

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And you shall as honourably be hang'd for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Be hang'd for receiving money?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: The Receiver is as bad as the Thief. Bear witness that will hang him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I receiv'd it as my wifes portion.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A cunning piece of policy, rob you of Gold and Jewels, run away with your Daughter, and being taken, say he receiv'd it as her Portion.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: That excuse will not do, he stole both it, and my Daughter too.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Daughter! what daughter did I steal?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Nay, she's not far off.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Aye, let me hear her say it.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: It's no matter whether she says it or no, she was found in the house where you was.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What's that to me, she might follow me for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: That's a cunning excuse, follow you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She's not so modest a woman, but that she might— Ask him there else.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: My Daughter not modest?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: As any woman in Town for any thing that I can say.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He'l not be known he told me. Well, if he won't say it, I know others that will; and if all be true is said, I am not the first man she has followed.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: 'Tis ungenerous, Sir Simon, now you cannot have the Lady to defame her.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: That is malice: if she followed you, did that Cabinet with the gold and Jewels follow you too?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: But she that had 'em did.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Cunning knave, he thinks to escape by laying the Theft on my Daughter still.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What do you tell me of your Daughter still? ask that man if it did not follow me, now you go to that.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ask me?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Did not a Lady come running after us?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: After who?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You and I.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A little while ago.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: In the street.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Not as I know.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Why? was not you and I together when a Lady came and beg'd our protection?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You amaze me! what Lady was it?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She that told us the story of her Uncle that would have sold her, and how she escap'd.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What means he?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Loe you there.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I ne'er saw you in my life till just now.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Hye-day, hye-day.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sure he is dreaming of Romances.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Or else he is mad.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: He is indeed much troubled with melancholy fancies, and melancholy is a sort of madness, that will be his best plea before a Judge.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I thank you Mr. Quack, you'l be sure to speak for your Patient, you play'd fine Pranks with me to day.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Come, Sir Knight, speak to the purpose: what is this to the Gentlewoman that followed you with the Cabinet?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: And what is the Gentlewoman to you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Yes, she is something to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What? because you bought her of her Uncle for half her portion?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: What means he now?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: And this night he was to force her to marry you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: He grows mad, stark mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You will be so ●on, when you know she is the Lady I have marryed, and that it was she gave me this Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Can you guess what he would be at?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Not in the least, I know nothing of any Marriage, Uncle, or any thing like it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pray where is this Lady wife you talk of?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She was too cunning for you, she slipt out at the back door, but if you find her, you'l be ne'er the better, I assure you, ha, ha, he. We are marryed, she is my wife now, and so pray set your hearts at rest.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: This is all but fiction; but we have proof enough to hang him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Here she comes that will clear all.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: My dear Princess!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: See she's displeas'd with you.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: There is much of Majesty in her frowns▪

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Ungrateful man, false and unconstant!

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Ah Soveraign Lady of my soul!

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Unworthy me, and my love.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: On his knees, behold your Mamamouchi falls.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: My dear Knight, my dear Sir Simon, have I found you?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Hau.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: My bosom shall be your sanctuary, and my arms magick Circles to keep thee here for ever; love shall be the sweet enchantment of our souls.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: My Princess is grown very loving, sure she mistakes her man.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: My dear bride, my dear wife, I've been at such a loss for want of thy presence.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How is that? his Wife!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It may be this is the Lady he has marryed.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: That is my Princess: away with him, if he has marryed her I'l hang him, because it is the speediest and surest Divorce can be had.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p:
No, malicious man: this Cabinet is mine. I took
it out of your custody, as unworthy to keep any thing that belong'd to a Princess: The Key your servant gave me when you cast your skin.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A Princess!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You see your fortune.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Am I then depriv'd of my love, a Princess, and revenge at once? Here comes Marina, I'l be content with my leavings, and marry her presently.
You come opportunely, Mrs. Marina, for in spight of that Princess there, I will make thee a Mamamoucha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What is that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Thou shalt be my Wife.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am your Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I thought my self concerned to repair the injuries you had done her. I wanted nothing before to gain her fathers consent, but an estate, and your bounty supplyed me with that.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Depriv'd of Marina too!

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Our business now was to ask you blessing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: A blessing without an estate is but a name, and you had that beforehand: Well, my comfort is I am a Mamamouchi.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, the Marriage is concluded, the Sultan is your Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: They were very eager, marryed before I come.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: They come now to ask your blessing, which the Turks do by bowing.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Princess, pine at my glory: behold me Father to the Grand Seignior, and the Worlds greatest Emperour bows to me. Love and conquest crown your lives.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: Your Son-in-Law but no Sultan, thanks you.

div.stage: Cleverwit bowing low lets fall his Turbant, and beard; then stands up and is discovered.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: How! Mr. Cleverwit?

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The same, Sir, I am no Turk great or little.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Am I no Mamamouchi then?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim. and B. Trick.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Friend, Mr. Doctor, what shall I say? must I be content with a pittiful Knighthood at last?

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: You'l find your self defeated there too: for, him you take for a favourite at Court, and a Doctor, is neither favourite nor Doctor; but one instructed and imployed by me to work upon your Capricio of setting up for a Gentleman, thereby to supply my own necessities, and by the event to bring you to see the vanity of your extravagancie.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: This is certain truth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: No Doctor?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Avoid Satan, thou art then the Devil.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: No, Sir, he is onward in his way, he is a Mountebanck, and may in time take his degree, as most of them do.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I have an excellent cure for your corns, powders for the teeth, oyntments for the itch, plaisters for byles, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Save you Mr. Doctor: save you Illustrious Mamamouchi, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well, I am vexed at nothing so much, as his getting my Princess; and could I be reveng'd of him for that, and his insolent insulting—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, Sir, now come I in with my discovery; and to gain your pardon for taking on me to be a Fencer to prevent your going to Sir Simon: and also my pretending to be a Norwich Merchant to forestal Sir Simons address to Mrs. Lucia, I will change the Scene of Sir Simons mirth, and let him know, that his Princess will not disdain to call me brother, and is by occupation a Sempstress.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Another turn yet?

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: I give you joy, Sir, ha, ha, ha, joy of your Princess, ha, ha, ha; hula baba la chou.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Where is the Cabinet, the gold and Jewels?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: Lass, Sir, they are none of mine.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: The Jewels, and part of the gold I seize on as mine.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: And the rest is mine, only lent to carry on the design of her personating a Princess.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No portion then?

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: My Dowry is my brain.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Wit without mony has long been the inheritance of our Family, and yours, Sir Simon, is a Family that has money without wit; 'tis a proper Marriage for you, and both our houses will be much the better for it hereafter.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Lord! Sir Simon, what luck had you to get my Princess from me, ha, ha, he, you'l have God knows what with her, ha, ha, he; you'l ne'er be able to count her portion, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: This Town produces nothing but wonders.

sp.speaker: B. Trick.
sp.p: And one was, that I should be fond of you, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: Bear it with fortitude, Sir Simon, such misfortunes sometimes befall Knights errants.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I ride the hind horse, I marryed but your Ladies Damsel; this is the hand-maid that carryed the luggage.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I am sorry for nothing so much as the loss of that, for it spoils half the conceit of a good subject for a Romance.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: But the turn of it makes it fitter for a Comedy in these days, and that is much better, for the Knight and the Damsel still shake hands at the end of the intrigue.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Save you, Sir Knight errant, much joy to you and the Lady of your adventures, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Laugh on, Sir, 'tis your turn now. Well, Lady Wife, and Brother-in-Law I embrace you both: I'l down to morrow into Suffolk where you shall be welcome: there people have either more honesty, or less wit: we have no cheating there, but with Lords and Jockies at Horse-races, and Ladies at Cards.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: And you, Sir Simon, have got one will match the best, if she holds on as she begins, ha, ha, he; Sir, I doubt not but she'l improve upon your hand, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Y. Iord.
sp.p: I am glad, Sir, you lay things no more to heart, if you please to make up the mony, Mr. Cleverwit has of mine in the Cabinet, a convenient Portion for my Sister, I'l restore to you one half of your estate.

sp.speaker: Iord.
sp.p: Well tho' now I affect not much to play the Gentleman, yet in this last act to cross Fortune, I will shew my self a Gentleman: Mr. Cleverwit I'l do it.

sp.speaker: Clev.
sp.p: I thank you Sir:

lg.l: To reclaim some men from their extravaganees,
We must appear indulgent to their humours,
And push them forward to undertakings
Yet more indiscreet, that rais'd high in hopes
They may from the unexpected events
Be convinc'd of their follies.
For fools are obstinate to good advice;
Experience, and not percept makes them wise.
OUr Author thinks 'tis not in vain to sue
For pardon here, for he is one of you;
And hopes he has some little int'rest here;
But yet his hope is not quite void of fear:
For by the grave it may objected be,
Who can at once mind Law and Poetrie?
But this he bid me say in his excuse,
A fortnights sickness did this Play produce▪
His sickness was the Bawd unto his Muse.
If after that he spent some idle time
In courting her, he hopes 'twas no great crime.
Fortune has punish'd him; for like a Whore
She lays the Brat e'en at his Chamber door;
The common'st Wench i'th' town could do no more.
The Father owns the child, which none of you
His fellow Students ever yet would do.
Tho' in hand-baskets the poor fools did ly,
And at your stare-case feet for succour cry:
For them—
He does his yearly contribution pay;
Therefore be kind to his but this one day:
For its relief you need not draw your purse,
Give it goodwords, and this shall back to Nurse.
